-	Stakeholder effects: Increased access to finance for SMEs  Through the Project, IFC expects that Equity BCDC will expand its SME portfolio from US$250 mln in 2021 to US$631 mln by 2026, representing a growth rate of 141% compared to 2021. Equity-BCDC will use IFC's de-risking instrument and advisory support to grow its SME portfolio in relative terms with a projected increase of the SME share of the Bank's overall loan book from 24% to 35% over the next five years
-	Stakeholder effects: increased access to finance for WSMEs - Over the project life cycle, the Bank expects  to increase its WSME lending from US$22 mln in 2021 to US$70 mln by 2026, representing a relative portfolio growth as a share of the SME portfolio from 9 percent to 11 percent.
Assessment of Contribution to Market Creation
-	Competitiveness  The Project supports the expansion of Equity-BCDC's SME finance business through an integrated IS/AS approach that is expected to serve as a meaningful market signal.

title: Partech Africa Fund II
content: IFC anticipates the project to increase access to equity alongside operational value add for startups across Africa. Access to venture capital in Africa remains low compared to most other emerging markets. The project is also expected to increase innovation in key markets across Africa through the support of market-disrupting digital business models. In markets where investees grow rapidly and become sizeable market players, innovation at scale can generate large impacts on a market by pushing traditional players to innovate and introduce digital solutions or reduce traditional incumbents' market share.  IFC anticipates the Fund Manager, raising a second Africa focused fund, significantly larger in size than the first one and having successfully invested in highly disruptive companies with Fund I, will demonstrate the viability venture capital in Africa. This is expected to attract more investors and incentivize more entrepreneurs to start businesses.

title: Chola 2022 Loan
content:
Stakeholders impact: 

Improved access to finance for MSMEs: The MSME sector plays a key role in the Indian economy, accounting for over 30% of the GDP and providing employment to more than 110 million people. Overall, the Covid-19 pandemic further intensified the issues around financing MSMEs. Commercial vehicle financing in particular was amongst the worst-hit segments in the financial sector given low vehicle utilization rates. Although MSME financing and CV financing have been recovering and are close to pre-pandemic levels, the recovery remains nascent, and inflationary pressures and supply chain bottlenecks pose a threat to the recovery. Continuing to provide access to finance to MSMEs will be crucial to ensure their sustained recovery from the pandemic. The proposed investment would support access to finance to MSMEs, for purchasing commercial vehicles, focusing on MSMEs in underserved areas like low-income states and rural regions of India. 

Market impact:

Resilience: This Project, along with other efforts conducted by IFC in the MSME segment, is part of IFC's systematic approach in India seeking to encourage FIs to increase access to finance for MSMEs by offering financial products and services catering specifically to this underserved segment. This project, together with other efforts by IFC, will signal confidence in financing MSMEs, and is likely to influence other financial institutions to grow their MSME portfolio and replicate this approach resulting in overall credit growth towards this underserved segment.

title: DCM Manappuram
content:
Stakeholders: Increased access to finance for underserved individuals. The Company will support underserved individuals in the country whose livelihoods were severely impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic. The Project will increase access to finance to these low-income borrowers who need funds to rebuild their lives, maintain small businesses and meet medical expenses. Along with the proposed investment, IFC will also support women, who are underserved as they often do not possess credit history or other assets to use as a collateral. Once the borrower engages with MFL through gold loans or micro loans, the borrower is also introduced to other products such as vehicle loans and home loans that help borrower's access to finance into other areas as well.

Inclusiveness: Gold lending addresses a crucial financing gap for the underserved, who often do not possess credit history or other assets to use as collateral. This investment will help MFL to extend lending to the underserved segments and is expected to stimulate other players in the market to increase their financing for un/underbanked when the country needs support to recover from the COVID-19 crisis.

title: Agrocorp Corporate Loan
content: The Project will support the Company's working capital facilities in Canada and Australia, ensure the smooth running of Agrocorp's facilities, and increase flows of wheat and pulses towards Bangladesh. Access to working capital is essential for agri-processing. The most significant, expected Project-level outcome is the impact on consumers in Bangladesh through the provision of safe, nutritious, and calorie-rich staple food. Beyond the Project, IFC anticipates that its financing will promote greater market resilience via market enabling channels.

title: CSE Loan
content:
IFC expects the Project outcome is improved quality of healthcare for patients of Luanda province of Angola. Beyond the project, IFC anticipates that the project has the potential to promote greater market resilience via demonstration channels.
It will also contribute to job creation, training, and development of the local community. Finally, demonstration and replication effects are expected to contribute to market creation through strengthening the resilience of a key healthcare provider, there is also potential for the corporate governance reforms at CSE to be replicated at other organizations in the country.

title: Sonker Refi
content: The Project has an AIMM rating of Good, based on an AIMM score of 53.  On an unadjusted basis (i.e., without the likelihood factor), the full potential AIMM score could reach 64.  The main project outcome is driven by the Stakeholder effect via increased port handling and storage of petroleum products in Egypt namely LPG and Gasoil, for domestic and commercial consumption, and Ammonia for exports.  At the market level, IFC anticipates this refinancing to enhance sector resilience through improved service offering via addition of alternative gateway infrastructure (the LBT).

title: BOP Grameen
content:
1.	Increased access to microlending: The Project will help increase access to microfinance borrowers in the low-income states of India and in rural areas.
2.	Market Creation: Resilience: IFC anticipates that the Project will support resilience among microfinance institutions in the market by bringing comfort to other local and international investors and catalyzing new and longer-term funding to the sector. By investing in CAGL, IFC will demonstrate to other investors the viability of supporting the sustainability and recovery of the bottom of pyramid lenders in the market.

title: DTRT CMT Expan.
content:
Economy-wide effects- The Ready-Made Garments ('RMG' sector in West Africa was badly hit during the onset of the pandemic and it is gradually recovering. Against this backdrop, the Project is expected to have various positive economy-wide effects, including i) domestic value addition and grow exports from the region through the expansion of the CMT operations and increasing product complexity (including potential production of PPE); ii) the direct creation of 2,900 formal manufacturing jobs, mostly for women, and a larger number of indirect jobs. 

Contribution to market creation Market Competitiveness: The Project is expected to improve the sector competitiveness through the expansion of the CMT operations to achieve scale, and therefore improve the efficiency of apparel production in the West Africa region and through backward integration (the 2nd phase of the Project). The capacity for DTRT to produce fabric for other companies in phase 2 will create an additional opportunity to serve other apparel manufacturers on the African continent, particularly those that are increasingly focused on establishing West African CMT operations and would benefit from locally produced fabrics (e.g., Ghana, Nigeria, Senegal, Cote d'Ivoire). As such, as the first mover in the Ghanaian market to integrate its operations at scale, DTRT can serve a significant demonstration effect, and case study for building the textiles sector in West Africa. This could have significant ripple effects, attracting other investors and players in the region, and permitting the West African textiles sector to follow the trajectory of other successful cases (Bangladesh and Sri Lanka) and to develop in ways that will not be possible without this type of first-mover investment.

title: FCS RE SCE Senior Loan
content: The most significant expected project-level outcome is the increase in access to finance for SMEs through the extension of additional leases and loans to SMEs. IFC also anticipates that the Project, together with complementary regulatory and sector capacity-building provided through the Africa Leasing Program launched in April 2021, has the potential to promote greater market competitiveness by aiming to address sector bottlenecks at the policy and industry levels and by enticing more financial institutions to offer leasing solutions to SMEs.

title: Tembici RI
content: As part of this Project, IFC seeks to support the acceleration of Tembici's expansion plans throughout the Latin America, and anticipates that Project Outcomes are Strong, derived from increased access to affordable urban micro-mobility services for individuals in Tier 2+ cities. Individuals in Latin American cities experience similar challenges in accessing mobility solutions compared to other cities, because of the availability of bus and metro systems, and a presence of bike sharing facilities. Beyond the Project, the Contribution to Market Creation is Moderate, aiming to increase the competitiveness of the micro-mobility market in the target countries, by triggering the growth of alternative docked bike sharing companies in the target countries.

title: LeapFrog Emerging Consumer Fund IV, LP
content:
LeapFrog is an experienced fund manager focusing on the financial and healthcare sector. Project level outcomes are delivered through increasing access to equity and value creation for mid-cap companies in Asia and Africa, including investees with an inclusive business model to serve underserved and bottom of pyramid customers; and increasing access to financial services for underserved private individuals and businesses including MSME customers across many emerging markets in Africa and Asia. The Fund Manager will support value creation in its investee companies through institutionalization, improved customer focus, and operational improvements including digitization leading to market expansion. 

Market creation is delivered by strengthening the competitiveness of Africa's PE market. The project supports an experienced emerging market-focused fund manager to raise a US$1 billion follow-on fund in the mid-cap market segment with a meaningful allocation of approximately 40% to the African market. Beyond the Project, the success of the Fund will encourage global fund managers to raise new or follow-on funds in the African PE market. In turn, this is expected to attract international institutional investors and reduce the need for capital from Development Financial Institutions ('DFI') for future fundraisings.

title: DCM Access Bank Total Return Swap
content: The project is expected to support the Bank's trade finance business and its capacity to sustain its customers' operations by improving access to stable US$ liquidity / working capital, and thus to benefit the value chains of exporters and other domestic players.

title: BaF Vietnam Agri
content: The Project has an Anticipated Impact Measurement and Monitoring (AIMM) rating of Good. The Project is assessed as part of the overarching programmatic intervention (ASF Asia Recovery Program) to respond to the impacts of the ASF on the regional pork industry. The most significant, expected Project-level outcome resulting from this expansion is the impact on consumers from the provision of safe pork at the time of severe supply shortage as well as implementation of advanced biosecurity procedures at the new farms. At the market level, the Project, alongside other planned investment, and advisory interventions, is expected to promote market resilience through improvement of biosecurity and disease management, both by supporting industry consolidation and disseminating best practices among smaller players.

title: DCM HIR Casa ABL
content: The most significant, anticipated Project-level impact is increased access to housing to middle-income households in Mexico. Beyond the Project, IFC anticipates that the investment will contribute to promoting inclusiveness via a focus on women head of households, which are financially underserved and have a lower access to housing finance in the country.  The Project is expected to enhance the warehousing capabilities of HIR Casa and help them to continue issuing securitizations in the Mexican capital market.

title: ONE IMPRESSION
content: The Project is expected to improve access to income opportunities for social creators in India, resulting in better livelihoods through earning opportunities on the technology platform, especially for women. Additionally, the Project is expected to support further integration of creators in the advertising value chain by enabling better linkages with brands.

title: Oasis Atlantico
content: IFC expects the Project outcome to be contribution to the recovery of tourism sector. Its development impact is expected through job preservation and purchase of goods and services from local SMEs and farmers. It will allow OA to mitigate some of the negative impact expected from the crisis, allowing OA not only to keep its staff on payroll but to pay their full contractual wages. Beyond the project, IFC anticipates that the project has the potential to promote greater market resilience by limiting disruptions along supply chains and ensuring continued supply of goods and services in sectors affected by reduced demand, price reductions and FX rate volatility thereby mitigating the effects of the economic downturn.

title: Platcorp
content: The most significant expected project-level outcome for the project is access to finance for MSMEs to support economic activity and resilience in the aftermath of the COVID-19 crisis. Beyond the project outcome, IFC anticipates that the Project will support resilience amongst microfinance and BOP finance providers, catalyzing investments in the sector by demonstrating the viability of lending to BoP providers and crowding in other sources of international and domestic finance in support of these lenders.

title: XW Bank Loan
content:
Stakeholder effects  Increased access to finance and green finance for WVSMEs: IFC anticipates that this project will increase access to finance for WVSMEs to support their business operations and growth. IFC expects this project to provide green finance for WMSMEs primarily for green transportation, including electric vehicles, climate-smart agriculture, energy-efficient appliance, and climate-related insurance. IFC also anticipates the Project will reduce GHG emissions by [13,738] tCO2e/yr.  
Market Creation - Competitiveness: The proposed Project will increase access to finance for MSMEs by demonstrating the viability and supporting the scaling up of lending to underserved segments through digital solutions. Currently, MSMEs, especially segments like WVSMEs, including those in lower-tier cities and counties of the country, are not readily served by the traditional and larger banks due to higher perceived risk. With optimized digital lending, XW Bank can acquire large numbers of underserved WVSMEs with very low marginal costs and demonstrate that digital solutions could be a viable and profitable way to address the access to finance needs of MSMEs. IFC anticipates that the market will see more traditional banks adopt digital solutions to increase the access to finance for WVSMEs.

title: CI Crediclub
content: Project-level outcome is: increased access to finance for micro enterprises, and especially women micro entrepreneurs in Mexico, where the access to finance remains low despite the significant role played by MSMEs in the economy. The main market-creation outcomes is: financial inclusiveness.

title: SMEV Ascent II a
content: Expected Development Impact includes: (i) Providing access to growth equity and business advice to underserved companies in East Africa; (ii) Contribution to market creation by enabling private sector development demonstrating the viability of PE investments in a low income IDA countries like Ethiopia and Uganda that are underserved by PE funds; (iii) Job creation and economic growth through financing SMEs, which are a growth driver in East Africa; and (iv) At the investee level - operational and financial improvements, implementation of best practice corporate governance and ESG improvements of local businesses.

title: Peo MSME
content:
Assessment of Project Outcomes Stakeholder Effects: Improved access to and quality of finance for individuals  The income streams of low-income individuals has been severely affected by the lockdowns, increased uncertainty, and a slow-down in economic activity in the wake of the pandemic. As the economy begins to recover, there is a need for access to capital to finance investments in productive assets to resume economic activity, and to adjust to the post-crisis economic environment. However, access to financing is limited for low- income individuals that were most affected by the crisis. In this context, the Project supports Peo to provide much-needed financing to assist low- income individuals especially in the agriculture sector in overcoming liquidity constraints and returning to their previous income generating capacity. 

Assessment of Contribution to Market Creation Resilience: IFC anticipates that the project will support resilience amongst microfinance and Base of Pyramid (BOP) finance providers by helping the market deal with the growing uncertainty and catalyzing investor response. A rise in non-performing loans, and disrupted borrower cash-flows has left banks reluctant to lend directly to BOP segments. Macroeconomic instability and uncertainty on long-term risks has led to increased difficulties in accessing medium-term funds needed to support the recovery and growth of lending operations. By investing in Peo, IFC will demonstrate to other investors the viability of supporting the sustainability and recovery of BOP financial service providers.

title: Sanima SME 2022
content:
Project level outcomes
Stakeholder effects: Increased access to finance for SMEs: SMEs in Nepal suffer from an estimated financing
gaps of US$2.9 billion, as SMEs face greater credit constraints especially during periods of tight liquidity. The Project will increase access to finance for underserved and rural SMEs to meet their requirements for working
capital and business expansion, and provide them with greater financing certainty to allow them to grow their
businesses.
Market creation outcomes
Inclusiveness: The Project will demonstrate to other banks the viability of SME centric business model (as
most of the 27 commercial banks have historically focused on the corporate segment) with a particular focus
on rural SMEs. This is expected to encourage other banks to adopt the business model and expand their
outreach to rural SMEs. The Project's catalytic effects will be augmented by IFC's systematic engagement in
Nepal alongside other banks to reach the underserved rural SMEs.

title: FCS Risk Envelope Bar Magen
content: The Project claims are stakeholders (farmers) as the primary claim via the provision of increased access to quality and affordable animal feed additives, and economy-wide effects on value added and job creation as the secondary claim. Beyond the project level, IFC expects the investment to promote market competitiveness in the livestock sector in Nigeria, by strengthening, through local production, the availability of key feed complements, such as salt licks, mineral blocks, and concentrates.

title: Zambeef III ZMW
content:
Project level impacts: (i) Economy wide effects: The project will expand Zambeef's production capacity and allow the company to source more inputs from local suppliers thereby supporting domestic value addition and associated job creation. The estimates of increase in GDP, value added, and jobs will be assessed using IFC's economic impact assessment framework. (ii) Stakeholders  Consumers: Increased access to quality and nutritious foods. The project will increase production of affordable quality, safe and nutritious meat products thereby increasing access to the products across the country especially among the largely  BoP consumers. Coupled with investments in the distribution system, the project is expected to increase the volume of meat products sold to consumers. 
Market level impact: Competitiveness: Adoption of new production technology, changes in market structure and greater value addition. IFC expects the project, through demonstration and replication channel, to contribute to increasing the competitiveness of the food processing sector through the Client's local processing of a range of food products. The project will support vertical integration by Zambeef and acquisition of on- and off-farm modern production technologies to expand production capacity and improve efficiency in production while ensuring product quality and safety. The project will ensure full implementation/acquisition of the requisite quality certifications. Taken together, these will show case the potential for vertical integration in the sector, adoption of modern and efficient production technologies to expand production of a range of food products at affordable prices. The project will not only shape the market structure by building the food processing base and market shares for the products but also reduce production costs and achieve economies of scale. This will encourage other players to replicate the business model to increase the competitiveness of the sector.

title: BOP Madagascar
content:
Project-level Outcomes: Stakeholder Effects: IFC anticipates that this Project will improve access to finance for MSMEs to support economic activity and resilience in the aftermath of the COVID-19 crisis. 

Market-level Outcome: Resilience: IFC anticipates that the Project will support resilience amongst microfinance and BOP finance providers catalyzing investments in the sector by demonstrating the viability of lending to BoP providers and crowding in other sources of international investors in support of these lenders.

title: ISC-EWA II
content: 1.	Increased access to pre-seed and seed stage equity in Colombia, as well as other countries across Latin America & Caribbean, especially for women led and women focused ventures.2.	Increased ability for startups to scale operations.3.	The Fund is expected to increase market competitiveness by developing the local start up and venture capital ecosystem.

title: Uhuru Growth Fund I
content:
Project level outcomes are delivered through increasing access to equity and value creation for small to mid-cap companies across IDA countries in West Africa, including a portion of companies being female-owned or led. The Fund Manager will invest all of the capital in IDA countries, with at least 60 percent going to countries other than Nigeria, such as Burkina Faso, Cote d'Ivoire, Ghana, Mali, and Senegal, where access to private equity funding is very scarce. The Fund will support its investee companies to grow by expanding domestically and regionally, driven by institutionalization, recruiting leadership, and operational improvements, including digitization.

Market creation is delivered by strengthening the PE ecosystem and market activity within West Africa, beyond Nigeria, a region where most countries have a nascent or non-existent PE market. It will also support IFC's broader strategy of restructuring the African PE market in response to a consolidating market by adding market capacity. Uhuru's success will help demonstrate that investing in nascent markets such as Burkina Faso, Cote d'Ivoire, Mali, and Senegal can generate returns to investors with sufficient deal flow and exit potential. This is expected to encourage other fund managers to invest in or enter the West African PE market beyond Nigeria, particularly the small to mid-cap market segment.

title: DARP SA Nimble
content: The key expected Project-level outcomes are (i) the offloading of retail NPLs in the Target Markets, which will release capital, decrease liquidity needs, and normalize retail obligations, allowing households to re-enter the banking system; and (ii) the enabling of local financially stressed companies to access special financing otherwise not available to them, so they can continue with their business activities, saving many of them from liquidation, and preserving jobs. Beyond the Project-level outcomes, IFC anticipates that the Project will improve financial integration through demonstration and replication, and enabling framework channels, supporting the creation of an enabling platform for cross-border investments in distressed assets to reduce NPL levels in multiple financial institutions.

title: Riverwood LAC II
content: The main project outcome is an increase in access to growth capital for investee companies, which, supported by Riverwood, are expected to achieve strong growth. The main contribution to market creation is an increased digital economy integration in Latin America through the support of technology and tech-enabled companies.

title: Coelba Disco
content: The proceeds of this loan will finance part of Neoenergia Coelba's capital expenditures in 2023, including network expansion and renewal (excluding transmission lines), substation upgrades and digitalization. Project Outcomes: IFC's investment will contribute to increasing access to energy in the state of Bahia, which has the largest rural population in Brazil. Neoenergia Coelba expects to add to the grid an average of 140,000 customers per year for the next 5 years. In terms of quality of service, IFC's intervention is expected to result in an improvement in the frequency and duration of interruptions, increasing the reliability of the power supply. Market Creation: This "super green" instrument is an innovative market structure that combines green use-of-proceeds and sustainability-linked pricing features. It is Neoenergia Coelba's and Neoenergia's first sustainability-linked financing, as well as one of the first sustainability-linked products in the Brazilian infrastructure market and the Latin American energy sector.

title: WCS FSDH Merchant Bank
content: The most significant, expected project-level outcome is to provide increased access to working capital and trade finance to borrowers of the Bank (SMEs and corporates) during a time of crisis. Beyond the project, IFC anticipates that its financing will promote greater market resilience by supporting the flow of liquidity in Nigeria and strengthen the market's ability to absorb shocks imposed by the current crisis.

title: Project Autumn
content: The Project is expected to have a high development impact. It is expected to promote greater financial sector resilience and provide further support to EGH in its country of operations.

title: Bocom Clean Cooking Facility
content: The most significant expected project-level outcome is increased access to LPG products to support clean cooking in underserved areas of the country. LPG use improves household's air quality especially for women and children compared the widespread use of firewood or charcoal for cooking. The project will also increase access to high quality lubricants in a market where access to lubricants is quite poor in most of the country, and thereby, efficiency of automotives' engine combustion is low with the consequent detrimental effects on GHG emissions. Beyond these, the Project will also contribute to mitigate one of the deforestation drivers by displacing the use of unsustainable firewood and charcoal, support job creation in Cameroon and contribute to the country's GDP through forward linkages with LPG retailers, and contribute significantly to improve the competitiveness of the LPG and Lubricants market in Cameroon through a sizable expansion in capacity, enhanced operational and distribution efficiency, and adoption of improved safety standards.

title: DCM TCHFL SB
content:
Access to housing finance: Through this investment, IFC will support TCHFL in expanding its housing finance portfolio and including sub-segments like affordable and green housing finance.

Competitiveness: The Project will promote sustainability by catalyzing the issuance of sustainability bonds as part of sustainable finance in India and more broadly in emerging countries. The market creation impact will be brought through demonstration and capacity building channels.

title: GWFP Volcafe
content: The Project is expected to reach 77,000 farmers in Uganda, Tanzania and Kenya, safeguarding farmer livelihoods by providing access to markets and access to sustainable farming practices. Volcafe provides technical assistance and training to farmers through its 'farming as a business' program, which aims to help farmers improve their coffee quality, farm productivity and yields, and train farmers on sustainable production, good agronomy, and making the best use of land. In addition, the program also helps them manage risks and exchange information with each other.

title: DCM TCCL SLB
content:
Increased access to climate finance - India has large climate financing needs as it has pledged that renewable energy (RE) will be 40% of the country's electricity generation capacity in 2030. The proposed investment will support TCCL to increase financing for RE projects.

Contribution to Market Creation: Sustainability: The Project will lead to increased sustainability by catalyzing the issuance of first sustainability linked instrument by a financial institution in India that follows the International Capital Markets Association (ICMA) Guidelines. Moreover, it will help establish standards for such issuance in the domestic capital markets and thus create an alternative asset class for channeling institutional investors in this domain. The market creation impact will be brought through innovation, demonstration, and capacity building channels. In addition, there is integration aspect of the market creation as well.

title: Zener SA, Togo
content:
According to the World Health Organization (WHO) in 2019, only 9.3% of the Togolese population consumed clean technologies for cooking. Firewood represents 99% of primary energy production , where more than 36% of the firewood is used by households for cooking.  Heavy reliance on biomass fuels for household consumption entails severe negative health effects. These fuels are inefficient energy sources and produce a range of pollutants associated with detrimental health outcomes. While replacing biomass with LPG remains a switch to fossil fuels, this change represents an important step in the country's move towards cleaner energy sources. The current use of biomass in Togo is unsustainable and contributes to the country's high levels of deforestation. 

The most significant expected project-level outcomes are increased access to LPG products, with improvements in household's air quality and resultant health effects, especially for women and children, especially in undeserved rural areas. Beyond the Project, IFC anticipates the Project will further promote Competitiveness of LPG production in the market through demonstration effects in other market players in improving LPG access, in particular to undeserved rural populations as an energy transition fuel.

title: GSCF VPBank
content: The development impact of the proposed project is expected to be delivered through: (i) increased access to finance for supply chain of agriculture export of Vietnam, including SME suppliers and agriculture exporters, and (ii) increased integration in the market via the promotion of supply chain financing.

title: BT SNP Blue Loan
content:
The project is expected to:
i) Help the country achieve its climate change mitigation targets by providing the first blue financing loan in the country and the region. Entire proceeds of IFC's loan will be used for financing eligible blue projects in Romania in line with IFC's Guidelines for Blue Finance. 
ii) Promote the blue finance concept in the market, eventually prompting other systemic banks to follow on with their own blue finance transactions, thus increasing the blue financing available in the country. 
iii) Enhance the resilience of Romanian banking sector by supporting the first MREL debt of the largest bank in the country. The proposed project is part of IFC's program to promote capital market deepening and financial sector resilience in Romania.

title: SABESP UCL
content:
Stakeholder impact: IFC will support investments focused on sewage expansion and water quality improvements in the state of S<e3>o Paulo.

Market impact: The use of performance-based contract as part of the Pinheiros River Cleanup Program demonstrates an innovative contractual model that can be used as reference for other water and sanitation companies to increase efficiency in meeting coverage targets, while boosting the sector's competitiveness.

title: E-buses Chile
content: The direct impact of the Project will be the reduction of the carbon footprint of the Red through the introduction of 992 E-buses that will replace part of the existing diesel bus fleet. At the market level, the Project will contribute to an increase the financial and operational resilience of mass transport systems in Chile by promoting a new model of private sector participation to deliver transportation services in an environmentally sustainable manner.

title: DCM BDO Blue Bond
content:
Increased access to finance for blue projects: The most significant expected project level impact will be derived from an increase in access to long term finance for blue financing projects in the Philippines.

Sustainability: Beyond the Project, IFC anticipates that the Project will contribute to market creation through sustainability via innovation, demonstration/replication, and capacity building channels.

title: Rupshi Foods
content:
Project level impact (Economy wide effects): The Project will expand RFL's processing capacities and allow the Group to source more inputs from local suppliers, which will support domestic value addition and associated job creation. Using IFC's economic impact assessment framework we estimate that the Project will lead to an annual increase in GDP of US$ 239 million from 2030. This comprises 15,400 new jobs, 14,900 indirect jobs. The GDP (value added) multiplier is US$ 1.04 million per million US$ invested while the employment multiplier is 67 jobs per million US$ invested. Based on the financial model, revenue is projected to increase by 296 million US$.

Market level impact (Competitiveness): Triggering new product offerings and supporting greater domestic value addition. IFC expects the project, through demonstration and replication channel, to contribute to increasing competitiveness of the consumer-packaged goods (CPG) sector and specifically in the production of dairy, bakery and confectionery products. The proposed investment will showcase the potential for domestic vertical integration downstream to take advantage of lower costs, security of supply and quality of inputs, and spearhead a replicable business model for other players with strong brand recognition, distribution strategy, lower cost of production per in-house production and scale of inputs, to increase their market shares through improvements in resource use efficiency, product diversity, quality and certification in a country where food quality and safety is a major concern. This will raise the bar in the CPG sector in Bangladesh and catalyze adoption of similar practices by other industry players.

title: NXTP Fund III
content:
i) The Fund is expected to provide value creation by providing operational support, access to follow on funding and networks. The previous funds show a good track record and during due diligence information on the average investee IRR, follow-on funding and value creation strategies used by the fund will be assessed to set targets and assess the intensity of the project.

ii) The Fund is expected to support innovative tech startups that can disrupt various traditional sectors. The investees' businesses models can strengthen supply chains by reducing the role of brokers and intermediaries, improve price transparency, and have a demonstration effect by catalyzing replication from new entrants.

title: LDC Brasil
content: The most significant, expected Project-level outcome resulting from this investment is economic benefits for farmers and environmental impact by providing incentives for zero deforestation or conversion of natural habitat, building farmer capacity in certification, energy efficiency, and conservation agriculture for input use. At the market level, the Project will contribute to strengthening sustainability of the soybean and corn sectors in Brazil with the potential to demonstrate the feasibility of full traceability.

title: Resource Partners III
content:
Project level outcomes are delivered through increasing access to equity and value creation for mid-cap companies in Poland and other countries in the CEE region, primarily Romania. Resource Partners is an experienced fund manager and will support value creation in its investee companies by improving operational efficiency improvements, leadership development, and international expansion. 
Market creation is delivered by strengthening the resilience of the PE market in Poland and Romania. The project supports an experienced fund manager to raise a follow-on fund in the small to mid-cap market segment Beyond the Project, IFC's support to Resource Partner's along with other Development Finance Institutions (DFIs) will help sustain investment activity during the current crisis and preserve market capacity supporting faster recovery, demonstrating resilience to shocks and encouraging commercial investors to return to the market.

title: BlaBlaCar
content: The development impact of the project will be via: (i)Project Outcomes (Stakeholders): Improved access to long-distance transportation services for passengers.(ii)Project Outcomes (Environment): GHG emission avoidance, through increased capacity utilization of personal vehicles. (iii)Contribution to Market Creation (Competitiveness): Creating a competitive market for long-distance carpooling services in emerging markets.

title: DFP Credicorp
content: IFC anticipates that the Project will improve the credit available for medium and larger size enterprises to support their growth. The longer-tenors and customized, flexible forms of finance will facilitate the borrowers' growth. Beyond the project-level impact, IFC anticipates that the project will promote competitiveness in the Colombian market by helping develop the debt fund market in Colombia. This will be achieved through the demonstration and competition channels.

title: Orizon Waste
content: The direct anticipated impact of this project is to increase recycling capacity in Brazil while also contribute to GHG emissions reductions associated with the use of recovered materials. At market level, the project will be one of the first municipal solid waste management facilities to implement at scale materials recovery measures in Brazil and lead to increased adoption of this business model by other companies in the sector, further developing the circular economy concept. The Project will also pioneer the use of a sustainability-linked loan in the waste and environmental services sector in Brazil and in emerging markets, contributing to their increased adoption and helping draw ESG investors to the sector.

title: DCM REGIO Fund
content: Reduction of Green House Gas Emissions: The project will make a significant contribution to reducing greenhouse gas emissions by financing eligible climate projects such as renewable energy, energy efficiency, green buildings, transport, and mobility.Promotion of green bonds best practice in emerging markets

title: Seacom Debt
content: The Project will contribute to the increased capacity of broadband networks and increased access, to IT services for businesses, potentially resulting in improved quality of broadband internet for end-users and enhanced productivity growth for businesses. The Project will also lead to increased competitiveness of the broadband market in selected countries, e.g., Ghana, via competition channels, and stronger economic integration in selected countries, e.g., South Africa and Kenya, by improving connectivity across value chains via the development of cloud/IT services. A successful expansion of submarine or terrestrial cable capacity under open access principles is expected to drop the wholesale price and level the playing field among retailoperators, thereby improving the competitiveness of retail markets with a market-wide improvement in affordability and quality of connectivity in the relevant target countries.

title: Avacare Global
content: The project helps finance a manufacturer and supplier of pharmaceutical and healthcare consumable products in Africa. The most significant expected project-level outcome is an increase in access to healthcare supplies such as pharmaceuticals, healthcare consumables and disposables. The project will also likely result in the creation of new jobs and/or economic linkages to the rest of the economy. Beyond the project-level outcome, IFC anticipates that its financing could support greater market resilience as spillover effects accrue to the healthcare supply chains in these markets.

title: Diamond Cement Guinea SA
content: The most significant, expected project-level outcome is driven largely by its contributions to stakeholder impacts, notably the availability of cement at a reduced price.<U+00A0>Beyond the Project, IFC expects the investment to promote market integration in Guinea by deepening domestic supply chains, as the supply of key construction materials for local infrastructure and housing will unlock a key bottleneck for the expansion of these sectors in the frontier areas of the country.

title: Imperial DTMC
content: The project outcomes rating is composed of two claims: (i) Stakeholder Effect via increased access to healthcare products. The global shortage of healthcare supplies has led to worldwide competition for these supplies, making it difficult  particularly in developing countries  to purchase  quality medical products at affordable prices. The Project will support operations in the Africa region, that will increase the distribution and sales of healthcare products that are needed in the response to COVID-19 and other diseases. The Project responds to the large need for improved healthcare logistics in Africa. This includes the need to improve cold-storage logistics as part of the roll out of COVID-19 and other vaccines; and (ii) Economy-wide effect via direct jobs created and gross value added. The project will help scale the production, distribution, and delivery of healthcare supplies that is likely to result in the creation of new jobs and/or economic linkages to the rest of the economy. To measure progress against this outcome, IFC will track direct jobs created.

title: Mibanco BOW
content: The most significant, expected Project-level outcome is improved access to and quality of finance for WSMEs in underserved regions of Peru. Beyond the Project-level impact, IFC anticipates that the Project is expected to further contribute to market creation through improved market inclusiveness via both the demonstration and replication and the capacity building channels.

title: LMI Holdings Ltd
content:
The
Project will improve the affordability of electricity supply in Tema FZ and
Dawa IZ, improve the quality of water supply to the Dawa IZ, and reduce the
associated CO2 emissions. The Project involves the construction of a 16.8 MWp
rooftop solar installation that contributes to improving competitiveness of the
industrial zones. It also adds a 4,000 m3/day water treatment plant, which will
serve new tenants in the Dawa IZ with reliable potable water.

 

At a market level, the
Project will demonstrate the potential of on-site solar generation as a
cost effective, reliable, and green alternative to thermal power from the grid.
This investment will be the first private sector-led utility scale solar
project developed by a Ghanaian company that can be replicated by other
high-volume customers. The water facility also constitutes the first investment
in Ghana to develop, build and operate a private-to-industries water treatment
plant that can be replicated by similar large-scale facilities not adequately
served by the water distribution network.

title: NMB GB
content:
Project Outcome:
Stakeholders Effect  Improved access to finance for WMSMEs: The Project will help address the large WMSME finance gap in Tanzania, which is estimated at<U+00A0>US$1.5 billion. NMB has been an active advocate for women financing in Tanzania, launching NMB Jasiri<U+00A0>, its women empowerment program in 2020.  IFC anticipates that the Project will provide financing for over 2,313 additional WMSME loans, growing NMB's outstanding loan portfolio in WMSMEs by US$7 million over the next three years. The expansion of the Bank's WSME portfolio is also expected to have job creation effects.<U+00A0> 

Contribution to Market Creation:
Inclusiveness: IFC anticipates that the first gender bond issued by the largest bank in the country will promote greater market inclusiveness though capital market development by introducing a replicable instrument to diversify funding sources for the underserved WMSME segment via the demonstration and replication channel.

title: Aadhar Debt
content:
Stakeholder Impact: 
Improved access to affordable housing finance: Rapid urbanization and the lack of affordable housing finance has led to a severe shortage of housing units in urban areas. Recent estimates suggest India's urban housing shortage was 29 million units in 2018, increasing by over 58 percent since 2012. The rural housing shortage also continues to be a concern and is estimated to be twice that of the urban housing shortage as the rural segment is less attractive to private sector developers. Housing financiers have been reluctant to finance the affordable segment due to the difficulties in assessing the debt servicing capacities of low- and middle-income group borrowers and the high costs of servicing such loans. IFC anticipates that this Project will significantly increase retail borrowers' access to housing finance and encourage homeownership for EWS & LIG segments. India's mortgage market depth (outstanding mortgage as % of GDP) is low compared to other emerging economies. Through this Project, and IFC's previous investments, IFC has been supporting the Government of India's initiative of 'Housing for All'.

Increased access to green affordable housing finance: Limited penetration of green housing is another key challenge in the housing market in India. IFC estimates a total green buildings and housing investment opportunity of US$1.4 trillion in India from 2018 to 2030, with the residential sector accounting for US$1.25 trillion (89 percent) of this opportunity. In addition to increasing access to affordable housing finance, the Project will also support Aadhar in growing its green affordable housing portfolio.

Market Impact: 
Competitiveness: The housing market in India is very active, however, a large proportion of the housing finance focuses on high-income or salaried groups, and low & middle-income groups remain unserved/underserved. In the context of green financing, the market for green affordable housing finance remains underdeveloped with a very few HFCs/ financial institutions focused on financing for green building/housing as green finance is considered expensive and thus not meant for the affordable housing segment. IFC's support through the project will promote greater competitiveness in the green affordable housing segment, by demonstrating the viability of providing such financing to lower income segments.

title: Anglo SDG Loan
content: The direct anticipated impact of this project is to contribute to improved quality of education and livelihoods for communities close to the Anglo American group's mining operations in South Africa. The project will introduce a sustainability-linked loan focused on community development initiatives, which is a new financing instrument in the South African mining sector, with potential uptake by other companies and investors as they increase the focus on sustainability.

title: Bauducco COVID
content:
The Project is expected to have positive economywide impacts in terms of job creation and value added, driven largely by the expansion of bread lines.
In terms of market impact, Bauducco is expected to increase competitiveness of the sector through demonstration and replication effects.

title: DCM Dimex ABL
content: The most significant, anticipated Project-level impact is increased access to finance for underserved pensioners in Mexico. Beyond the Project, IFC anticipates that the investment will contribute to promoting market competitiveness via the demonstration, innovation, and replication channels. IFC's engagement with NBFIs with unique business models to reach MSMEs aims to exert an increased competition in the market that is underserved by large banks.

title: India BEF IV
content:
Project level outcomes are delivered through increasing access to equity and value creation for mid-cap companies in India with a focus to also support companies with a scope for expanding significant operations in low-income states. MOA is an experienced fund manager and will support value creation in its investee companies through operational improvements by leveraging its in-house team of experts, in turn, positioning companies for market expansion across India.  
Market creation is delivered by strengthening the competitiveness of the private equity ('PE') market in India. The project supports an experienced fund manager to raise a follow-on fund in the mid-cap market segment. Beyond the project, the success of the Fund will encourage other local fund managers to raise new or follow funds in the segment. In turn, this will attract domestic and international institutional investors and is expected to reduce the need for development financial institution ('DFI') presence in the market for future fundraisings

title: VPB SrLoan2022
content: The development impact of the proposed project is expected to be delivered through: (i) Increased access to finance for SMEs and WSMEs, (ii) Increased access to climate finance with a focus on SMEs access to green finance, thereby promoting green finance products by SMEs, (iii) expected reduction in GHG emissions, and (iv) promotion of international green lending principles in Vietnam.

title: CAFSA SME-Climate Loan
content: The most significant, expected Project-level outcome is the increased access to finance for SMEs and HEVs. Beyond the Project, IFC anticipates that the investment has the potential to increase Costa Rica's competitiveness by increasing access to climate finance for climate-smart vehicles through demonstration and replication.

title: SLGP RSF NSIA Benin
content: The most significant, expected Project-level outcome is an increased access to finance for SMEs, including to Women-owned SMEs (WSMEs). IFC also anticipates that the Project has the potential to promote greater market inclusiveness through demonstration of the commercial viability of lending to underserved SME segments such as WSME and VSE.

title: Visum REIT
content:
Infrastructure development: The Project will improve firm's access to high-quality and modern urban infrastructure through new potential industrial, office, healthcare, and retail property developments. Furthermore, the modern industrial warehouses established through the Project can contribute to efficiency gains and reduced operational costs for local businesses and supply chains. Class A developments can be significantly more efficient with lower operating costs than existing properties in the market.
Environmental effects: All new developments will be certified as green buildings. In addition, Visum is expected to embark in a decarbonization pathway under the IFC GRIP ('Green Pathways for Real Estate Institutional Portfolios') program, through which some existing buildings will be upgraded to attain energy efficiencies and reduce their carbon footprint and new acquisitions/developments will also have lower carbon footprint. Improving energy-efficiency in the commercial property sector is critical for coping with energy supply constraints while contributing to GHG emission reductions. 
Green Building ('GB') Standards: The penetration of GB standards in Colombia remains low. The share of green buildings for new developments is currently at 4%, with an objective to reach 100 percent by 2030. Since 2011, the uptake for GB in Colombia remains mandatory, however, wide adoption of GB has proved a challenge due to (i) limited uptake of GB financing business by banks, (ii) very limited use of GB certification to two regions, Cundinamarca and Antioquia, (iii) lack of technical capacity and human capital in the GB area and (iv) lack of awareness by the government, FIs and leading developers.

title: Circulate Capital Ocean Fund I-B
content: (i) The Fund will provide access to equity capital for innovative companies tackling plastic waste challenges in South and SE Asia, and ii) value creation for the Fund's portfolio companies through hands-on operational support, as well as opportunities for partnerships with Circulate Capital's network of global corporate partners through its prior fund, Ocean Fund I.

title: VIB Housing Loan 2022
content: The development impacts of the Project will be delivered through (i) improved access to finance for homebuyers, and (ii) improved lower-income segments' access to housing finance.

title: BOP Elet Capital
content:
Stakeholder Effect: The most significant project-level outcome is derived from increased access to finance for MEs and underserved individuals with a focus on women enterprises and micro-housing, particularly in rural areas.

Resilience: IFC anticipates that the Project will promote increased resilience, achieved though supporting access to finance for MEs to withstand financials and economic shocks caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. IFC will also support the private sector in the economic recovery process after the crisis, shortening the time for the most vulnerable to return to their previous income generating capacities.

title: BOP Bailyk Finance
content:
Stakeholder Effect: The most significant project-level outcome is derived from increased access to finance for MEs and underserved individuals with a focus on women enterprises and micro-housing, particularly in rural areas.
Resilience: IFC anticipates that the Project will promote increased resilience, achieved though supporting access to finance for MEs to withstand financial and economic shocks caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. IFC will also support the private sector in the economic recovery process after the crisis, shortening the time for the most vulnerable to return to their previous income generating capacities.

title: BOP IMON SL
content:
Increased access to finance for MSEs through provision of financing to make investments in inventory and inputs necessary to resume full economic activity post COVID.
Contribute to market resilience in the Tajik financial sector by sending a positive signal to boost investor confidence and demonstrating the viability of supporting the sustainability and recovery of financial institutions.

title: Exacta Asia Investment III, LP
content: Expected development impact outcomes include i) providing access to equity capital for lower mid-market companies in SE Asia, and ii) value creation for the Fund's portfolio companies through hands-on operational and strategic support.

title: Sudameris Loan
content:
IFC anticipates that the Project will contribute to narrow the finance gap for SMEs in Paraguay, supporting financial inclusion in the country. The SME finance gap in Paraguay is US$3.9 billion according to the SME Finance Forum, representing approximately 14% of the country's GDP. Informal micro and SME demand for finance is estimated at another US$3.6 billion. Improving access to finance and thus productivity of SMEs is crucial for the development of Paraguay's economy, as SMEs are a key driver of economic growth and job creation. Furthermore, 30% of the proceeds are expected to be used to originate loans to WSME, a key underserved sub-segment in the economy. 

The Project will also increase the competitiveness of the SME financing sector by enabling the Bank to expand its operations. Through the Project, the Bank will demonstrate to other players the commercial viability and business opportunity presented by underserved SMEs proven by its growing market share.

title: Santa Priscila
content:
The most significant, expected Project-level outcome is environmental improvement driven largely by Santa Priscila's electrification project which is expected to significantly reduce Greenhouse Gas emissions by replacing energy from diesel power generators with electricity. 
Beyond the project level, IFC expects the investment to improve resilience of the sector through strong demonstration and replication effects, largely at primary production level. The investments in efficiency-improving automation and connection of the farms to the electrical grid will motivate other players to replicate similar practices.

title: WCS CR Zenith
content: The most significant project outcome will be access to working capital finance/liquidity to Zenith Bank and through Zenith Bank, its customers. The IFC facility will support Zenith Bank's capacity to sustain its customers' operations and to expedite post-crisis recovery. The project is also expected to help preserve Nigeria's private sector by supplying foreign currency working capital to support operations of businesses during the crisis, thus making it more resilient.

title: VNGH
content:
The Project has an anticipated AIMM rating of Satisfactory.
The main expected project-level outcome stems from preserving and maximizing
positive environmental effects by optimizing the performance of operating solar
projects. Beyond the Project, by structuring the A loan as a certified green
loan according to the internationally recognized green loan principles
('GLP'),  the proposed investment is expected to increase integration by
promoting green financing in a market with large climate-smart investment needs
but limited local green financing capacity.

title: IHS Zambia COVID
content: The most significant, expected project-level outcome is increased capacity of mobile networks in Zambia, achieved by building additional mobile towers, potentially resulting in increased access to mobile connectivity for individuals and businesses.

title: CIF-II
content:
Project level outcomes are delivered through increasing access to equity and value creation for mid-cap companies in India. Creaegis is a first-time fund manager and will support value creation for digital companies by providing both capital and active management support, including digital transformation, mentorship, and building systems to institutionalize' company operations.
Market creation is delivered by strengthening the competitiveness of the private equity ('PE') market in India. The project supports a first-time local fund manager in the early growth stage PE market segment. Beyond the project, the success of the Fund will encourage other local fund managers to raise new or follow-on funds in the early growth stage PE market segment. In turn, this will attract domestic and international institutional investors, reducing the need for development finance institution ('DFI') presence in the market for future fundraisings.

title: ESR India
content:
The Company plans to construct multiple Grade A warehouses in several cities in India such as Chennai, Hyderabad, Kolkata, NCR, Mumbai, etc. The increased availability of logistics infrastructure will allow firms from various sectors to (i) reap efficiency gains through improved access to modern equipment and amenities, (ii) reduce supply chain costs and  (iii)  meet the growing demand for E-commerce. E-commerce transactions in India are expected to double by 2025  underlying the importance of providing the necessary urban infrastructure. Furthermore, in Tamil Nadu, the regional government enacted a plan to expand manufacturing activity in the same timeline, again supporting the future demand for high-quality warehousing.  

Contribution to Market Creation: 
India's rental warehousing market is fragmented and dominated by one large player and several small players. IFC anticipates that the proposed investment will provide a significant positive step forward for the Indian warehousing market, which is moving towards greater consolidation. If the Company is successful in attracting new tenants and offer their properties, it will help demonstrate the Company's modern and cost-efficient business model, which will improve competitiveness of India's Warehousing sector if other players were to replicate.

title: M&J Garments
content:
Economy-wide impacts: The Project will enable the Companies to move up the manufacturing complexity curve to more value-added products and services. IFC anticipates that the Company's operations will contribute to Bangladesh's economy through increased exports and backward linkages to the local supply chain. The Project also has a strong employment effect and will create thousands of additional direct and indirect jobs and female employment in the value chain. 
Competitiveness: This Project and IFC's sectoral programs in the RMG sector in Bangladesh are expected to contribute to preserving Bangladesh's competitiveness as a global player in the textile and apparel market, by helping Bangladesh move towards higher value-added production.

title: GTFP Natixis ALG
content: The project builds on GTFP's global platform, increasing access to trade finance to emerging markets. The project will provide increased access to trade finance to Issuing Bank's customers, including both corporates and SMEs. On the market side, the project will further connect the Issuing Bank's cross border connections, increasing the country's integration through both financial and real sector channels. It will help link more traders to other countries and connect the country's financial markets more deeply.

title: ISC Seedstars
content: IFC anticipates that the project will result in: (i) increased access to very early-stage equity and increased ability for startups to scale operations and receive follow on funding. (ii) increased market competitiveness by developing the local start-up ecosystems and initial building blocks for venture capital markets across the countries invested. Supporting the development of early-stage ecosystems is critical to create a constant and quality pipeline of investment opportunities that investors at Series A and beyond depend upon. (iii) improved gender representation across Seedstars' investment and activities across various markets of operations.

title: SHTF Sec II
content:
Stakeholders impact: 

Improved access to finance for MSMEs in the transportation sector: The MSME sector is extremely critical for the development of the country as it accounts for over 30% of the GDP and provides employment to more than 110mn people. The Covid-19 pandemic has aggravated the already weak economic environment for the MSME sector, and continuing to provide access to finance to MSMEs will be crucial to ensure their sustained recovery from the pandemic. The proposed investment would support access to finance to MSMEs, particularly micro enterprises, for purchasing commercial vehicles, focusing on MSMEs in underserved areas like low-income states and rural regions of India. 

Market impact:

Beyond the project level outcomes, IFC anticipates the investment to promote greater resilience in the market via innovation, demonstration, and replication channels. This project will signal confidence in financing MSMEs, and support an increase in financing to MSMEs, especially micro-enterprises. The project also supports integration of the securitization market in India, by attracting long term capital from institutional investors.

title: Kordsa Global
content: The Project's expected development impacts include (i) higher export generation with increased sales, higher taxes; (ii) improved competitiveness of Kordsa; and (iii) job preservation and creation with skill development in a highly technical industry.

title: Celsia Revolving WC
content: The Project-level outcome rating is Moderate, with a High likelihood of achievement. The likelihood assessment is positively influenced by (a) the existing commitment to building these assets after the successful outcome of Celsia Colombia's bid in the two latest power auctions in Colombia, (b) traditionally favorable regulatory sector framework; (c) Celsia Colombia's strong experience developing energy infrastructure in Colombia; and (d) the advanced stage of the analysis of technical and E&S risks. The proceeds of the Facility will be used for several diverse corporate needs. Due to limited visibility at this stage regarding the specific use of proceeds, the project-outcomes assessment is based on an estimate of the potential outcomes focused on supporting Celsia Colombia's development of two wind farms that are a high priority in the Company's expansion CAPEX pipeline. These two projects have a total capacity of 359 MW for a combined generation of 1,329 GW per year (P50).Environmental Effects: The Project is expected to partly support the expansion of Celsia Colombia's renewable energy assets, thus contributing to the improvement of the power sector's carbon footprint in Colombia. The GoC has committed to reducing the Country's GHG emissions by 20 percent below business-as-usual in 2030 under the NDCs submitted as part of the Paris Agreement. The thermal generation currently represents 31 percent of Colombia's installed capacity, and the share of CO2 emissions from the power sector accounted for 27 percent of the country's total emissions in 2014. By supporting Celsia Colombia's pipeline development of two wind farms, the Project is expected to increase by 10x the non-hydro renewable energy generation capacity in Colombia by adding 359 MW to the existing 36 MW. IFC anticipates that the Project will contribute to the country's climate mitigation agenda by supporting the displacement, particularly during drought events, of high polluting thermal power sources such as coal and heavy fuel oil, with non-conventional renewable energy (reducing the associated carbon emissions). The two wind farms are expected to reduce GHG emissions by approximately 411,990 tons CO2 per year once fully operational. To measure progress against this outcome, IFC will track reduced CO2 emissions per year.Stakeholder Effects: IFC anticipates that the Project will support the development of NCRE capacity in the Atlantic Coast region in Colombia. The power supply in this region is notoriously unreliable, with power outages of approximately 96 hours per year, one of the highest in the country and well above the 36 hours national average. La Guajira region is particularly exposed to drought and poorly equipped to meet demand through hydroelectric generation. The wind farms will expand electricity generation capacity in the region to improve the quality of electricity service. IFC's financing proceeds could also be used to finance other projects in the Company's renewable energy pipeline. To measure the progress of this outcome, IFC will track Company's wind energy capacity in Colombia

title: Fouta Cement Corporation
content: (i) Economywide and employment effects: The Project will lead to the creation of jobs, including  during the construction period and in the transportation and distribution network. Beyond the number of jobs created, the Project will support the continuous development of technical skills, which will improve the overall industrial capacity of the country. (ii) Market impacts- Competitiveness: IFC expects the investment to promote competitiveness in the Liberian cement market by allowing a key competitor to install a local grinding plant and thus retain competitive pressure on the dominant market leader.

title: GTLP MUFGECA Inc
content:
In the COVID-19 environment, this Project positions the private sector as key to support the economic
recovery process during this acute shock, shortening the time it will take for the most vulnerable to return to
their traditional income-earning opportunities. The Project Outcome will be realized by providing access to
finance/liquidity to the ultimate beneficiaries, the Turkish exporters/importers to sustain operations and to
expedite post-crisis recovery.

title: VLP Dry Port
content:
Project outcomes
Stakeholder effects: IFC anticipates that the Project will support improvement in transport logistics by introducing the first international standard dry port in Laos. Laos is a landlocked country with an underdeveloped logistics services industry and with transport prices twice as high as in other Association of South East Asian Nations (ASEAN) member states. Prior to the operation of the Project, the cross-border trade in Vientiane was served by the First Friendship Bridge Checkpoint, which suffered from severe capacity constraints and with limited ability to process the increased traffic from the Laos  China Railway. The Project is expected to offer access to advanced logistics services including multimodality, trans-shipment and value-added services with potential cost and time savings. 
Market Creation Integration: The Project is expected to improve integration by establishing a strategic node for trade in the region, as well as setting a precedent for the remaining seven dry ports (Pursuant to art. 8 of Decree No. 513/GOL on Dry Port dated 4 August 2021, there will be a total of 9 dry ports to be constructed including Thanaleng Dry Port in Laos) to be constructed. The lack of strategic inland nodes (dry ports) to facilitate trade between Laos and its neighbors have led to sub-optimal solutions where trade not always moves through the most direct route. The Project will improve integration by helping Laos to transform from a land-locked to a land-linked country, leveraging its strategic location and provide a range of services to help improve connectivity within Laos and the ASEAN member countries, and thereby facilitating efficient and cost-effective bilateral and transit trade.

title: KV Asia II
content: Expected development impact outcomes include i) access to equity capital for mid-cap companies in SE Asia and ii) hands-on engagement and value-addition at the portfolio companies' level.

title: RSE COVID GTST Mauritania
content:
The Project is expected to have a strong contribution to the economy's resilience as it supports the energy sector and the entire value chain to sustain operations during this acute COVID shock.  Disruptions in supply of petroleum products would acutely affect the functioning of key industries (mining and fishing- among the top GDP contributors) and more generally the macroeconomic stability and GDP growth of this IDA country. 

The Project also supports regional integration by keeping trade routes and channels open, especially to Mali and other landlocked countries in the region. While the overall Correspondent Banking appetite of international banks towards emerging market has drastically decreased, particularly in Africa, this project would contribute to keep critical correspondent banking links active with local financial institutions.

title: BOP PRASAC 2022
content: The development impacts of the Project will be delivered through (i) improved access to finance for MSMEs; (ii) strengthened resilience among MSMEs in Cambodia by assisting financial institutions to improve responsible finance practice; (iii) increased access to climate finance, to support PRASAC to grow green financing, thereby catalyzing the private sector in Cambodia to adopt environmental and social sustainable principles, setting standards and reducing greenhouse gas emission.

title: Arrendamas
content: The most significant, anticipated Project-level impact is increased access to finance for SMEs in Mexico. Beyond the Project, IFC anticipates that the investment will contribute to promoting market competitiveness via the demonstration, innovation, and replication channels. The Project will continue to build on IFC's asset based lending (ABL) work done in the past in the secured transactions framework by using the mechanism of ABL as the foundation for an innovative scheme aimed to create scale to efficiently address a market need. By diversifying Arrendamas' funding sources, the Project will directly enhance the use of this kind of structure in the Mexican market. As seen in other existing ABL projects, the Project is expected to enhance the warehousing capabilities of Arrendamas and help them to continue issuing Asset Backed Securities in the Mexican capital market.

title: DCM Red RealFIDC
content:
IFC anticipates that the Project will support an increase in access to finance for Brazilian SMEs, helping to address an SME finance gap estimated at US$437 billion, the ninth largest gap among 128 developing countries, and approximately 25% of the GDP. Moreover, SME finance has decreased during 2020-2021 in a period of recession when banks were restricting their loans and going for less risk portfolios. 


IFC anticipates that the Project will contribute to greater resilience in the SME finance market through demonstration and replication channels by unlocking alternative funding sources for lenders in the SME financing segment. The credit market in Brazil is characterized by a high degree of concentration where banks control the lion's share with the top 5 banks responsible for about 70% of the total credit volume in the country. This market dominance enables banks to realize good profits dampening their appetite for targeting underserved segments such as SMEs. Worse still, banks perceive SMEs as a high-risk segment and retrench from this segment especially during stress periods such as the COVID-19 pandemic. This flight to quality phenomenon was evident during the pandemic as there was a decline of approximately 3% in the share of SME financing by commercial banks in 2021 to 61.7% from roughly 64.7% in 2020.

title: Innova VII
content:
Project Outcomes:
- Increased access to private equity capital and value creation for mid-market companies in Poland and the CEE region.
Contribution to Market Creation:
- Strengthen the competitiveness of the private equity market in Poland and the CEE region

title: SLGP Agri Sogesol
content:
The project is expected to have development impact in terms of:

(1) Access to Finance for Agri-SMEs. The project will provide a leading MFI in Haiti with an efficient risk mitigation tool, so it can continue to sustainably increase access to finance for Agri-SMEs who are perceived to have higher risk profiles. By sharing 50% of the risk on each eligible loan, the RSF will enable Sogesol to take on additional risk and cater to the financial needs of underserved segments, including in the regions affected by the recent earthquake and tropical storm, and to gain better knowledge of them.

(2) Competitiveness  IFC expects that the RSF will generate changes in the market by demonstrating that when approached with the right tools and processes Agri-SMEs can be a commercially attractive and viable asset class, despite the perception of high risk. This should give comfort to other financial institutions in Haiti to also extend their services to these segments, making the financial sector more inclusive.

title: ISC VP Fund IV
content:
The Project follows the AIMM (Development Impact) Rating for the Startup Catalyst Envelope.

IFC anticipates that the Project would result in increased access to seed stage equity for digital startups in Nigeria, Kenya, Egypt, and Rwanda, countries where venture capital availability has increased in recent years, although challenges for seed- and early-stage startups, especially in Rwanda, persist and continue to deter their establishment. The Project is also expected to increase the ability for startups to succeed and scale digital businesses, through the Fund's mentorship and window for follow-on funding.

Beyond the Project, this investment is expected to contribute to developing the start-up ecosystem and venture capital market in Nigeria and other operating markets, by demonstrating the commercial viability of the VC fund model in the country. IFC's support also enables creation of a constant and quality pipeline of investment opportunities that investors at Series A stage and beyond depend upon.

title: GTLP SMBC III
content: The development impact thesis shared by all projects under the IFC Crisis Response Facility is that by supporting clients' capacity to sustain operations during an acute shock, IFC best positions the private sector to support the economic recovery process, shortening the time it will take for the most vulnerable to return to their traditional income-earning opportunities.

title: DCM Mega SBond
content: The most significant, expected Project-level outcomes are improved access to finance for small and medium enterprises (SMEs) especially women-led SMEs and SMEs engaged in sustainable activities. Beyond the Project outcome, IFC anticipates that the investment will have the potential to promote integration in the Mexican financial market via the demonstration, innovation, and replication channels. The Project will support the first issuance of a SB by a non-bank financial institution in Mexico, paving the way for other FIs to carry out similar issuances.

title: Contactar Loan
content: The most significant, expected Project-level outcome is increased access to finance for microentrepreneurs from Colombia's underserved segments including rural, low-income, and agribusinesses. Beyond the Project-level outcomes, IFC anticipates the Project has the potential to promote greater market competitiveness through the demonstration and replication channel.

title: RALFI IFN SA ROMANIA
