content: The most significant, expected project-level outcomes are: increased access to sustainable energy / green leasing through the climate-dedicated leasing line in Ukraine for high-efficiency machinery, equipment, logistics, and distributed generation renewable energy equipment, resulting in GHG emission reduction along with potential MWh saved and MW RE capacity installed (potential GHG emission savings are targeted at 107,000 tCO2e/yr); and increased access to financing for underbanked SMEs with a particular focus on the agri sector. Beyond the Project, IFC anticipates that the Project has the potential to promote greater sustainability through capacity building and demonstration channels, and market competitiveness through demonstration and replication channels.

title: DCM CHIB Green
content: Project Impact Assessment: - Stakeholders impact - IFC anticipates the project will provide up to US$150 million in long-term financing for climate-smart and environmentally friendly projects such as renewable energy, green buildings, energy efficiency, and water conservation and waste water treatment projects. Expected impact includes: i) increase in accessibility of financing for green projects to China Bank's customers; ii) improvement of China Bank's employees' skills related to climate change financing; and iii) provision of longer tenor funding and new instrument for China Bank to access capital markets. - Environmental and/or social impact - IFC anticipates the project will reduce CO2 emissions in the Philippines. The expected reduction on sub-borrowers' emissions and technical data on reductions in CO2 emissions will be collected and quantified through IFC's CAFI tool. Market Impact Assessment: IFC anticipates that the project will have the following market impacts: 1) it opens the market for climate finance and ultimately attracts more financial institutions into this space (competitiveness); and 2) it supports China Bank's contribution to the country's objective of tackling climate change challenges (sustainability) by adopting environmental sustainability principles and developing a new asset class that promotes greater market sustainability.

title: RBL Debt I
content:
Shareholders impact: The project is expected to improve access to finance for the MSME sector in LIS, by earmarking the proceeds towards these enterprises. In addition, the Project supports the growth of climate smart financing.
Market Impact: The funding to LIS will enable greater financial inclusion in these states which are the poorest states in the country with significantly low penetration of financial services. In addition, by supporting climate smart financing, the project will encourage sustainability through demonstration and replication channels.

title: Alpha Feed
content:
(i) Through the Project, the Company will reach and support the growth of about 80,000 additional aqua farmers. Most of them would be switching from other feed providers whose quality of feed or of technical support does not match Alpha's. While all input providers focus on extension work to build customer loyalty, Alpha's differentiating factor is the type of technical support provided that takes a more enterprise level approach focusing more on-farm profitability and sustainability.
(ii) The Project is categorized as climate adaptation. Climate change related higher temperatures increase the risk from eutrophication that impacts water quality. The extruded feed, due to its characteristic of better water stability and consequent lower losses within the water system, reduces such risks. Additionally, better feed conversion ratio (FCR) supports lower impacts on water quality and addresses higher fish metabolism that is related to temperatures.

title: TerraPay
content:
Project outcome: stakeholders:  IFC's investment will allow TerraPay to execute on its strategy to scale operations as a hub enabling interoperable, real-time, cross-border transactions between MTOs and mobile money operators. By providing pre-funding of mobile transfers as well as faster and cheaper clearing and settlement of international payments, TerraPay will remove a significant barrier for transfers to mobile money accounts, enabling instant payments across interoperable networks of operators.  By enabling the electronic low-cost transfer of funds, the Project will encourage a greater share of formal remittance payments and strengthen the link to financial inclusion by enabling recipients to access a wide range of financial and non-financial services through their mobile wallets.

Contribution to market creation: competitiveness: IFC anticipates that the Project will contribute to promoting systemic changes in the international remittances market in Sub-Saharan Africa, by lowering barriers to entrants for new MTOs, promoting price reduction through competition and by enabling a lower-cost model for remittance transfers directly into mobile money and bank accounts. The Project is aligned with World Bank engagements with regulators at the country and regional levels seeking to promote competition and modernize payment infrastructure to reduce frictions in international and regional remittance flows, and ultimately improve affordability of remittances. 

Contribution to market creation: integration: IFC anticipates that the Project will contribute to fostering the integration of service providers across international remittances channels, by enabling interoperability through the integration of data and financial flows facilitated by the platform.

title: Humo SL LCY
content: The development impact of the Project is expected to be: (i) increased access to financial services for the underserved MSEs, (ii) increased access to housing microfinance for underserved population of rural areas in Tajikistan. Beyond the Project, IFC anticipates that the Project will promote greater inclusiveness by fostering housing microfinance through a leading MFI via capacity building and demonstration effect.

title: ARVAND SL LCY
content: The development impact of the Project is expected to be: (i) increased access to financial services for the underserved MSEs, (ii) increased access to housing microfinance for underserved population of rural areas in Tajikistan. Beyond the Project, IFC anticipates that the Project will promote greater inclusiveness by fostering housing microfinance through a leading MFI via capacity building and demonstration effect.

title: Grainpulse
content: The most significant, expected project-level outcome is an increase in the supply and delivery of quality crop-specific fertilizer for smallholder farmers in Uganda. Beyond the Project, IFC anticipates that its investment will increase competitiveness in the country's fertilizer sector by changing the market structure through demonstration and replication effects, capacity building and skill development.

title: GWFP ETG SCB IV
content: The renewed facility is expected to continue having the following development impacts: (i) support of commodity trade finance for importers/exporters in emerging markets; (ii) increased access to trade finance for critical commodities, especially in the agro-commodity sector in emerging market; and (ii) improved market integration by facilitating intra-regional and south-south trade for commodities and enhancing connectivity of real sector firms into value chains

title: ISFC Equity
content:
Access to Education: Access to quality education is one of World Bank Group's key engagement areas. The current funding will enable ISFC to fund schools to expand their existing facilities and improve their current infrastructure which will impact students across the country. 

Competitiveness: The education finance sector is very nascent with only three education infrastructures focused NBFCs in the country. The Affordable Private Schools are severely underfunded and IFC's investment will demonstrate the sustainability of this business model and will be an intervention in a space where most mainstream financiers are reluctant to lend.

title: New Crystal
content: IFC expects the Project to improve access to high-impact health treatment for underserved populations in the area around Ashaiman and Tema in the Greater Accra Area, Ghana. IFC also expects the Project to increase the competitiveness of the market by expanding a high-quality provider of healthcare services in a market characterized by many low-quality healthcare facilities.

title: KMRC Equity
content:
Accessibility and affordability of housing finance: the proposed Project will allow KMRC to offer longer tenor funding to primary mortgage lenders in Kenya which in turn will enable primary mortgage lenders to offer longer-term mortgage loans to borrowers, ultimately increasing access and affordability of mortgages. 

Job creation: through the proposed Project, IFC will promote creation of indirect jobs through the construction of residential houses in Kenya

title: Revelo
content:
(i) Job Creation: Revelo will facilitate the placement of thousands of professionals in new jobs across Brazil, helping both SMEs and large enterprises alike to improve their productivity. 

(ii) Hiring Equality: The Revelo platform helps to reduce hiring biases, thereby allowing women and other minorities to have a higher likelihood of getting hired.

title: Umeme Capex [2019-2024]
content: The Project will support the growing demand for electricity in Uganda, and contribute to ongoing efforts to increase access to electricity. This will help fulfill the Government of Uganda's efforts to improve electrification rate from the current 27% to 60% by 2027, and complement the significant growth (almost double) in generation capacity expected by 2020 (from 183MW Isimba and 600MW Karuma dams, and small solar/hydros). In addition, the Project has potentially significant indirect and induced effects on value added and employment as Umeme's network expansion plan focuses on zones with high electricity demand and economic growth potential. Finally, it will improve resilience of the main distribution network in Uganda and reduce losses, through adoption of advanced smart technologies, adequate maintenance and upgrade of ageing assets.

title: Masrik Solar
content: The project's development impact includes: (i) Reduction of GHG emissions, by increasing the share of electricity supply from renewable sources, (ii) Improving energy security and lowering generation costs, by reducing the country's reliance on imported fuels for power generation, and (iii) Further strengthening competitiveness of the sector, by supporting the development of the first competitively tendered utility-scale solar IPP in the country.

title: WCS - NIC Asia Bank Nepal
content: The Project is expected to increase access to working capital financing for SMEs in Nepal, which suffer from a significant gap between the current supply of finance and their demand for credit. Working capital is necessary for SMEs to finance their daily business operations, source supplies and pay employees. SME growth ultimately facilitates business growth, job creation and income generation, especially in key productive sectors of the Nepalese economy. The financing will also support key industries, as the ultimate recipients of funds would include buyers of raw materials, processors and manufacturers that support growth.

title: SLGP RSF Union Bank
content:
1.	Stakeholders Impact - IFC anticipates that the RSF will allow the Bank to sustainably improve its SME portfolio risk profile and hence contribute to increasing access to finance for SMEs including to underserved segments such as WSMEs and SMEs operating in the Northern and Delta regions in Nigeria.                     
                             
2.	Inclusiveness - IFC anticipates that capacity building offered by the SLGP and IFC Advisory Services will help Union Bank to scale-up its lending activities to SMEs in Nigeria, thereby demonstrating that this underserved segment could be commercially viable. This should give comfort to other banks to also extend their services to this segment, making the banking sector more inclusive. Union Bank recently launched a Women's product alpher and the proposed project is expected to expand its current offerings to individual women and women-owned businesses.

3.	Competitiveness: Through the demonstration and replication channel, Union Bank's expansion of its SME portfolio will demonstrate to the wider local market that SMEs, particularly currently underserved segments (WSMEs and SMEs including those operating in the northern and delta regions in Nigeria) are an attractive asset class. The Project is, therefore, expected to increase the market's competitiveness as other market participants also move down-market to replicate the Bank's success. Also, once the viability of this product and segment is established, it is likely to be replicated more broadly across the banking sector in the Country. Banks will start scrambling for market share on this newly bankable segment, progressively lowering their pricing as perceived risk reduces and more suited products are introduced to the market.

title: Baobab MicroCred LCY multi-country facility
content:
The most significant, expected Project-level outcome is increased access to finance including at longer terms by underserved MSMEs including Women owned MSMEs (WSMEs). Beyond the Project, IFC anticipates that the Project has the potential to promote greater market inclusiveness via demonstration and replication channels. 
Development Impact is expected to be measured based on the following factors: 
-	Stakeholders effects: change in accessibility - in the context of bridging finance gap for MSMEs (incl. WMSMEs and agri-MSMEs located in rural areas) in six countries by deploying (i) its products and services and (ii) access to scarce medium- to long-term finance. 
-	Stakeholder effects: change in affordability of finance for MSMEs - by (i) deploying digital channels, agent network along with multiple products offering to lower the access to finance cost for MSMEs. 
-	Inclusiveness: by demonstrating to other Financial Institutions the viability of product offerings and digital channels that meet the funding needs of WMSMEs and MSMEs in remote locations.

title: Ramex
content:
The Project is expected to have a GOOD development impact
-	At the Project level: The most significant, expected project-level outcome is the growth in the exporter's sourcing network, combined with an increase in producer vanilla yields and certification. 
-	At the Market level: IFC anticipates its investment in the Malagasy vanilla supply chain, coupled with the activities of IFC Advisory, will encourage systemic changes to the vanilla market in the country by increasing sustainability, through replication and demonstration effects and building capacity and skills.

title: IPM Debt Facility
content:
(i) Stakeholder effects: The Facility will improve access to finance for secondary cities in South Africa with limited access to commercial debt. The Facility supports implementation of a portfolio of municipal infrastructure projects, and by leveraging the municipalities balance sheets, these municipalities can accelerate much needed infrastructure investments. Furthermore, the Facility will support projects that address climate change, with potential implications on access to urban infrastructure services.

(ii) Integration: The Project would mobilize capital for municipal finance, with the potential to engage new investors to the underserved secondary cities. Furthermore, IFC's engagement will create a demonstration effect, which is expected to mobilize greater commercial financing in future fund-raising efforts by these municipalities. 

(iii) Resilience - By enabling secondary municipalities to establish a borrowing track record, the Project contributes to reducing dependence on government transfers for municipal infrastructure projects. The Facility will also provide technical assistance to build capacities of secondary municipalities, including in financial planning.

title: GWFP ETG SCB III
content: The renewed facility is expected to continue having the following development impacts: (i) support of commodity trade finance for importers/exporters in emerging markets; (ii) increased access to trade finance for critical commodities, especially in the agro-commodity sector in emerging market; and (ii) improved market integration by facilitating intra-regional and south-south trade for commodities and enhancing connectivity of real sector firms into value chains

title: Trukker
content:
This Project will result in positive outcomes for the relevant parties in the logistics sector in Middle East (cargo owners and truck owners/drivers) and the market at large. 
Benefits for stakeholders include reduced costs and better quality logistics services for customers and increased income and ancillary services for truck drivers. Furthermore, TruKKer is expected to increase competitiveness of the logistics sector through demonstration channels. TruKKer will bring innovation into the logistics market by disrupting traditional incumbents and intermediaries, which will result in increased price transparency and efficiency at market level.

title: NepalPSW-RMDC
content:
1. Stakeholders Impact: The project is expected to improve access to finance for low-income households, particularly to unbanked women and VSEs in underserved regions in the country, through RMDC's Partner Organizations. 
2. Market Impact: Through the project, RMDC will be focusing on helping exisiting and new MFIs in underserved regions, and will onlend to its Partner Organizations to expand credit to the most underserved socio-economic groups, segments and areas, primarily women that MFIs are not catering to especially in harder to access hilly and remote areas. With a focused strategy to cater to underserved segments, this market represents a sizeable opportunity not only for RMDC, but also for its Patrtner Organizations and other players aiming to participate in this growth segment, and would lead to a more balanced and inclusive growth of microfinance in Nepal.

title: FCS RE-Biovanilla
content:
The Project is expected to have a GOOD development impact
-	At the Project level: The most significant, expected project-level outcome is the growth in the exporter's sourcing network, combined with an increase in producer vanilla yields and certification. 
-	At the Market level: IFC anticipates its investment in the Malagasy vanilla supply chain, coupled with the activities of IFC Advisory, will encourage systemic changes to the vanilla market in the country by increasing sustainability, through replication and demonstration effects and building capacity and skills.

title: FCL II
content:
Stakeholders Impact:
IFC expects that the Project, through the introduction of new products and an increase in production, will increase the procurement of food produce sourced from local farmers, thus increasing farmer incomes. The penetration of FCL's wholesale centers in rural areas combined with its retail management platform will benefit small retailers through the introduction of technology and infrastructure. IFC also expects long-term benefits for end-consumers in terms of safer and higher-quality food products and lower product prices. Beyond the Project, IFC anticipates that the investment will promote greater market competitiveness via demonstration and replication.

title: Packages RE
content:
The Project is expected to have the following development impacts: 
a) Environmental sustainability - the Project's focus on resource efficiency improvements identified by IFC Advisory Services.  The Company and its subsidiary will be able to reduce both energy and water consumption translating into GHG emissions reductions. These resource efficiency improvements are particularly relevant in the context on Pakistan because the country is facing both water and energy shortages. 

b) Supply chain effect:  The Project will have economy-wide effects by generating increased local value addition by strengthening the domestic manufacturing base. In addition to direct jobs, the Project will support the creation of indirect and induced jobs through backward and forward linkages.

c) Market creation: The Project will result in an increase in competitive pressures due to both product and process innovations. The Company's market standing ensures that the resulting improvements in the cost structure and margins will be visible to other market players and motivate matching actions. In addition, some of product lines that the Company will be manufacturing as a result of the Project previously were not available in the domestic market. The identification of a new promising market will expand the Company's own ability to serve its clients better and lead other sector player to look for ways to expand their product offering accordingly.

title: Deepak Fert
content:
Access: The Project will help the Company ramp up the production and distribution of specialty fertilizers in India. The Project will also allow Deepak to increase its IPA production capacity in India by 100,000 MTPA.
Climate Change and Resource Efficiency: This Project is expected to contribute to climate change mitigation by net reduction of GHG emissions. This will be achieved by installing N2O catalyst conversion devices at all existing Nitric Acid manufacturing processes at Taloja. 
Competitiveness: IFC's engagement will likely contribute to increase competitiveness in the fertilizer sector as the Company works on innovation and expanding the product offering in the market.

title: Accion Quona Inclusion Fund
content:
The Fund will add value to its investee companies by (i) providing access to VC capital in underserved markets mainly in Latin America, Africa, South and Southeast Asia; (ii) the ability of the Investment Manager to provide active governance support through its board representation, and leveraging expertise and networks including from the fund's LPs. 
The Fund focuses on financial services to underserved consumers and MSMEs. Investees may include providers of electronic payment services, challenger banking, innovative credit or insurance, and financial advisory, reaching unbanked and underserved individuals and businesses.

title: Conaprole 2019
content:
Farmers Reached: The Project will result in a 16% additional milk intake capacity for Conaprole, which would translate into large production volumes of raw milk for the cooperative members. The production of high value-added products such as infant formula will allow Conaprole to generate better returns for its membership base. 
Environmental outcomes: Conaprole has a few areas of improvement on the E&S front (ammonia safety, occupational safety and health, waste water treatment). IFC's continued engagement together with the Cooperative's strong commitment will contribute to the adoption of best industry practices.

title: ISC Sarmayacar
content: (i) Increased access to capital for early stage tech enabled startups in a nascent ecosystem with an increased focus on supporting women entrepreneurs; (ii) Improved investee growth as the fund manager will actively engage in professionalizing the investee companies to help them grow their product offerings, increase headcount and potentially expand into new markets, and (iii) market creation through increased competitiveness of local VC market, reduction in risk perceptions and support of entrepreneurship ecosystem especially initiatives supporting investment readiness for early stage women entrepreneurs.

title: FCS RE MALI SHI
content: The most significant, expected project-level outcome is the increased income for ~120,000 new and existing shea nuts collectors in Mali, primarily women. Beyond the project, IFC anticipates the investment will increase competitiveness in Mali's shea nuts sector through demonstration and replication effects, and capacity building and skills.

title: KTDA ICD
content: The Project develops cargo freight logistics infrastructure in the city of Nairobi, which improves capacity and affordability of services. At the market level, the Project contributes to improving integration of the logistics networks centered around the Port of Mombasa and the new standard gauge railway (SGR) line linking Mombasa to Nairobi, by improving the Port's hinterland footprint and connectivity.

title: DCM Alpha Rom
content:
Market Impact: IFC anticipates that the Project will support development of the Romanian mortgage market and capital markets development in issuance of a new covered bond instrument.
Project Impact: Romania's mortgage market is the smallest in relative terms in the EU at less than 10% of GDP, and the Project is expected to directly support end customers through new supply of mortgage loans.

title: ACLEDA subdebt 3
content:
(i) Increased access to finance: Through this Project, IFC expects to increase access to finance for the underserved SMEs and women-owned SMEs in Cambodia by expanding number and volume of loans provided by ACLEDA to SMEs and women-owned SMEs in next 5 years. In addition, by supporting ACLEDA's growth strategy with focus on SME and women-owned SME segments and digitalization IFC anticipates that this Project contributes to improving quality of financial services by broadening access to digital financial products and improving banking service delivery via digital channels.
(ii) Improved inclusiveness: This Project reflects IFC's strategic engagement in Cambodia's banking sector by supporting ACLEDA's sustainable growth with focus on the base-of-pyramid and digitalization. By building market capacity that opens new market opportunities for digital banking products and services to help improve Cambodia's financial sector's competitiveness and promote a cashless economy.

title: DCM Aavas NCD II
content: The Project is part of IFC's programmatic approach to develop the affordable housing finance market in India, where only 5% of adults have an outstanding housing loan and the housing shortage is estimated at over 60 million units. While expanding its mortgage portfolio, AFL will demonstrate its financially sustainable approach to serving the un(der)served segments, which can be replicated by others in the market.

title: Apetit
content: The most significant, expected Project-level outcome is the provision of safe meat and associated products to the domestic consumers and expanded income opportunities for the local farmers. In addition, the Project will contribute to strengthening the competitiveness of Kosovo's meat processing sector by showcasing modern production practices and international food safety standards, which would be disseminated though demonstration and replication effects.

title: MTPL
content:
Economywide and employment effects: 
a) Exports and value addition: The Company estimates exports to account for 70-80 percent of sales and contribute to India's forex earnings. The Project will support value-addition in the domestic rubber product industry
 b) Employment: The Project is expected to create significant direct local employment by creating 1,500 additional jobs in phase 1 alone. 
Stakeholders Impact 
c) Access to affordable customized agriculture tires to improve mechanization in agriculture and thereby, productivity. Customized tire products (OHT) lead to better traction, lower downtime and result in an increase in higher productivity. The Project will increase availability of value brand products (defined as the brands that are able to offer a quality competitive product at a lower price), which are more affordable than the regular customized tires. 
d) Expanding outreach to more farmers and low-income states (LIS) with better extension services: The Company plans to onboard and extend attractive credit terms to distributors and wholesalers, who are mostly SMEs, to further market the product and enhance awareness of the use of customized tires to farmers. 
e) Better productivity through investments in modern machineries and training; The Company aims to set their level of productivity to be higher than the India industry average and more aligned with the industrial benchmark in Europe and North America, through improvement in machineries and training. 
Market Outcomes:
f) Competitiveness: Increased penetration of value brand OHT in India: Penetration of OHT in India is still relatively lower compared to developed markets such as EU and North America and other emerging markets outside.  The Indian OHT market is less mechanized and more price sensitive due to low farm incomes and as a result the product range in Indian markets is not as specialized as in the EU and North America, where more application specific solutions are available. IFC anticipates more investments in this sector will happen, increasing the degree of customization and product range available, thus resulting in an increased penetration of OHT in India.
g) Integration by way of increased participation by Indian OHT tire players in the global market: The size of OHT segment globally is still relatively small compared to the entire tires industry at ~10% of total tire industry. At present, value brands hold around approximately 30% of the global market share, with Indian players holding half of this market share. Indian players such as the Company have the advantage to produce more of value brand segment of OHT tires, given conversion costs in India are lower than in any other manufacturing bases. This Project will demonstrate the competitiveness of Indian players in the global market and increase the overall share of Indian value brands.

title: PCH Green Bond
content:
The Project will increase access to climate finance for SMEs in the ProCredit group's countries of operation and support the transition of the countries in the regions in which PCH operates from high to low carbon economies.

Environmental impact - The project will provide financing mainly for energy efficient measures, renewable energy and other environmentally friendly measures

title: Bank One I
content:
Project-level development impacts:
1) Stakeholder impact: IFC anticipates that the project will increase access to finance for underserved SMEs.
2) Economy-wide effects: By supporting the financing of SME through Bank One, the Project is expected to help contribute to job creation and economic growth.

Market-level development impact:
1) Competitiveness: In supporting Bank One, the Project can contribute to greater diversification, innovation and competitiveness of the local banking landscape.
2) Inclusiveness: IFC anticipates that the Project will enable BBML to sustainably expand its financial services to underserved SMEs, thereby demonstrating their bankability and encouraging other financial
institutions to also expand their services to this segment.

title: Pasabahce Egypt
content:
Employment Creation and Skill Transfer: The Project is expected to create more than 300 direct jobs and 100 indirect jobs in Egypt. The Project will also enable skill development of the local workforce through Pasabahce's transfer of its global know-how and labor standards. 
Increased Economic Returns: The Project will promote Egypt's export activities and foreign exchange generation through increased production levels and export-oriented sales.
Improved overall standards: The Project is expected to have a positive impact on the environment given improved energy and cost efficiency as well as cleaner production that is envisaged from renovation investments. The Project will also contribute to the improvement of existing production thanks to Pasabahce's transfer and implementation of modern production methods which is expected to result in higher value-added products.

title: PC Capital Development Fund II L.P.
content:
Project Outcomes 
Stakeholders - Improved Access to Capital for SMEs in the Mexican PE market: The Fund will provide access to growth capital with an average ticket size of US$5 to 10 million in 6 to 8 Mexico SMEs, with total commitments expected to be up to US$20 million including follow-on investments for platform building and M&A.

Stakeholders - Increased Investee Growth: The Fund is expected to add value to its investee companies by employing similar value creation strategies as Fund I through four key value-add approaches; (i) DD and Structuring; (ii) Operation; (iii) Governance; and (iv) Financial optimization.

Contribution to Market Creation 
Competitiveness: The project is expected to strengthen the SME segment of the PE market by demonstrating proof of concept of this business model and contributing to attract further funding into the underserved SME PE space. This is expected to result in the crowding in of new funds in the SME segment of the markets, which could occur via emerging new fund managers or existing fund managers targeting this segment.

title: BG Housing
content: The most significant expected project-level effect is increased access to housing finance for low and middle income households in Panama, and climate investment in the Panamanian market. Beyond the project-level effect, the proposed project will both promote inclusive home-ownership and financing of climate smart sub-projects in solar power generation, green buildings and energy efficiency.

title: SLGP RSF NSIA
content: The most significant, expected Project-level outcome is an increase in the availability and affordability of lending to SMEs, including to Women-owned SMEs (WSMEs), small/very-small enterprises (VSE/SE) and SMEs making climate related investments. IFC also anticipates that the Project has the potential to promote greater market inclusiveness through demonstration of the commercial viability of lending to underserved SME segments such as WSME and VSE/SE.

title: Helios Investors IV, L.P.
content:
Project Outcomes:
- Stakeholders - Access to growth capital for Fund investees: The Fund will provide access to growth capital by investing between US$30-200 million in at least five companies across Africa.
- Stakeholders - Increased investee growth: The Fund is expected to add value to its investee companies through a focus on operational value-add in four main areas: (a) leadership and organization; (b) strategy and execution; (c) operational excellence; and (d) governance.

Contribution to Market Creation:
- Competitiveness: The Project is expected to increase competitive pressures within the African PE market by demonstrating the viability of PE investments in a region which is suffering from a lack of investor confidence.

title: Famoco
content:
Project Outcomes: Stakeholders

Access to Transaction Accounts: The project will support Famoco's efforts to grow its clients' agent networks across emerging markets in Africa and Asia. Compared to existing solutions, Famoco addresses important sustainability challenges for payment schemes and mobile money networks, to meet increasingly stringent KYC requirements and enables more data security. The number of devices deployed is projected to grow significantly as a result.

Access to Payment Services: The project will support Famoco's plans to expand services for the digitization and management of humanitarian payments on behalf of the World Food Program (WFP) and others. This includes facilitation of government payments (salaries, subsidies, etc.), and to work with payment service providers to expand their networks enabled with POS devices to accept digital payments. The number of POS-enabled merchants is expected to grow significantly as a result.

Contribution to Market Creation: Integration

IFC anticipates that the project will enhance market integration by promoting linkages across payments networks and digital service providers through an open loop payment system, from the existing usage of services that is limited to P2P transfers using closed loop payment schemes which are non-interoperable and limit the opportunity for growth and delivering value to users.
Networks of agents using Famoco solutions would be leveraged to integrate additional services ranging from simple transactions, such as bill and mobile payments, to more complex ones, such as micro-credit and disbursing government payments. The hardware component would enable the provision of these services, while Famoco will customize its software solution as a platform to deliver them, enabling the integration of payment and data flows across financial and non-financial services and leading to a growth in the services accessible to users, and value to merchants and service providers in the market.

title: BAM Loan
content: Despite the significant role played by SMEs in the Guatemalan economy, as it produces 40% of GDP, the amount of lending to these companies is constrained. The SME financing gap in Guatemala is estimated at US$15 billion, or 20% of GDP. Furthermore, the estimated unmet housing demand in Guatemala is large at around 1.8 million homes. IFC anticipates that the project will increase access to SME and housing finance and contribute to narrowing the financing gap for these segments in Guatemala.

title: Access Tier II
content:
1. Combined with Access Bank's merger with Diamond Bank PLC (the largest retail/SME bank in Nigeria), the funding under the proposed project is expected to enable the Bank to leverage its new distribution channels to reach a wider group of MSMEs and women-owned MSMEs by improving accessibility to finance. 2. IFC anticipates that the Project will increase financial access for climate smart investments by providing long-term financing to Access Bank enhance the Bank's capital base thereby enabling it to scale up its lending to corporates with climate-smart activities, as this is in scarce supply in Nigeria. 3. In terms of environmental and social effects, this project will support Nigeria's climate agenda by reducing greenhouse gas emissions. 

Contribution to Market Creation: 1. Inclusiveness: The Project will contribute to a more inclusive MSME finance market by supporting the Bank's capital base to promote market-wide adoption of products across the Bank's network. 2. Sustainability: IFC's engagement with Access Bank will help build capacity in the Nigerian banking system to scale up green financing with the introduction of tools to identity, appraise and report on green assets, as well as green certification standards.

title: Humania
content: The project-level impact will come through: delivering high-quality care to patients; creating new career opportunities for medical professionals; and increasing the depth and quality of local medical professionals through improved training and experience. Humania's contribution to market creation will largely be centred around: 1) increasing competitiveness through being one of the first scalable, private players; 2) demonstrating a new staffing model that increases quality and lowers costs; 3) increasing resilience and sustainability of the health system through developing local medical professionals; and 4) increasing coordination within the healthcare system through SGH specialty clinics (Cairo).

title: Massader School Rooftop PV Program
content: The project is expected to: (i) improve the quality and affordability of energy supply in the WB&G; (ii) reduce the average cost of energy to residential and commercial customers; (iii) benefit the government from fiscal savings as a result of avoided energy expenditures on the public schools where the rooftop solar panels will be installed; (iv) increase cleaner energy supply that is expected to result in a reduction of an estimated 30,000 tons of CO2 emissions annually; (v) contribute to market competitiveness by supporting the first large scale solar PV plant selling electricity to Discos with long term PPAs in WB&G and (vi) contribute towards the WB&G's power sector resilience through increasing use of a local renewable resources and hence reducing dependency on imports.

title: IP Senior Loan
content: The key development impact of the proposed project is increased access to finance for SMEs in Uzbekistan, thus contributing to economic growth, market resilience, and job creation in the country.

title: TMFL SME Financing
content:
Stakeholders impact: The project will provide an additional US$400 million of direct on-lending to SMEs in LIS of India, a segment that is currently under-served in India. It would also support formal job creation by contributing to improvement in economic activity. 

Market Impact: The project is a part of a series of counter-cyclical interventions IFC is undertaking in the NBFC sector in India with leading institutions to support the market by increasing funding to select NBFCs to strengthen their balance sheets so that they can provide finance access to underserved borrowers. The proposed investment will focus on CV financing in the LIS and thereby, support inclusive growth.

title: Amru Rice
content:
At the Project level, expected outcomes include increased offtake of rice from smallholder farmers, improved farmer incomes and strengthened farmer resilience to market volatility and contribution to disseminating best sustainability practices (resource-efficient, climate smart, incl. provisions for addressing forced/child labor and biodiversity risks in the supply chain).

At market level, IFC anticipates that the Project will enhance the competitiveness and sustainability of the sector by showcasing the benefits and modalities of contract farming as well as the superior financial business outcomes of focusing on more niche product lines, such as organic or SRP rice.

title: 3B Hotels
content:
- Jobs: The expansion will create 112 new direct jobs. In addition to the direct jobs created through the hotel's operations, the Project will create temporary jobs during its construction period, and a support a number of indirect jobs through its supply chain. Direct employees will benefit from training, contributing to the upskilling of the country's workforce, as the Project is expected to hire low skilled, low income local employees, and train them to gain basic skill sets.

-Local Linkages and Community Engagement: 3B is committed to developing local communities and expects to source as much as possible through local suppliers, to train its suppliers to help them reach required quality standards. Some of the activities organized by 3B during its circuits (e.g. paid visits to local villages and bringing tourists to local markets and cooperatives) will create additional business opportunities for local entrepreneurs. Also, 3B is expecting to continue its community engagement programs with generous donations, support to the vulnerable and the promotion of football among the local youth.

-Tax Benefits: The Project will result in fiscal benefits through increased tax generation.

title: EVTL Expansion
content:
The Project is expected to have the following development impacts: 
a) Environmental sustainability - the Project is expected to support energy transition in Pakistan towards cleaner fuels by increasing access to reliable supply of LPG, which has low indoor health hazards and greenhouse gas emissions relative to alternative conventional fuels like firewood, kerosene or charcoal. 
The Proposed Project will allow the Company to implement 3-year terminal rehabilitation capex program covering some high priority scheduled maintenance and terminal rehabilitation that is essential for its continued safe and efficient operations.

b) Stakeholders Effects:  The Project will have economy-wide effects by substantially alleviating current deficit of LPG in Pakistan and improving access to cleaner fuels for rural households, as well as automotive sector consumers. Extension of LPG capacity will also provide additional business opportunities for thousands of Small and Medium Enterprises operating in the downstream LPG distribution business, such as LPG cylinder distributors, fueling stations and others.

c) Market creation: The Project will result in systemic changes to the existing LPG market in Pakistan through implementation of infrastructure to import, store and market larger quantities of LPG which is expected to substantially increase the local availability of LPG.

title: HFE Bhadla
content:
1. Increasing clean energy production: The Project will contribute for meeting the country's energy demand by using an environmentally friendly source of energy.
2. Climate change mitigation: IFC's investment will support clean energy production with associated avoidance of GHG emissions.

title: SMBC ECA RSF II
content: The proposed project is expected to provide financing to key financial intermediaries in the ECA region. Indirectly, this increased capacity will also improve the availability of credit to local producers and importers along the value chain and in a wide variety of sectors. IFC's support is much needed in the region to help financial intermediaries build capacity for their funding needs.

title: DCM MMFSL II
content:
1.	Stakeholders impact: The project is expected to improve access to finance for the MSME sector particularly women owned enterprises and those enterprises in LIS, by earmarking the proceeds towards these segments. It would also support formal job creation by contributing to improvement in economic activity.

2.	Market Impact: The funding to LIS will enable greater financial inclusion in these states which are the poorest states in the country with significantly low penetration of financial services. In addition, focused funding towards women owned enterprises will encourage economic participation and empowerment of women. The success of this investment is expected to encourage further market development.

title: Protea Bonanza
content: The most significant development impact is on stakeholders, with local employees and suppliers benefitting from training, employment and growth opportunities. The Project will promote enhanced competitiveness in the tourism/hospitality sector by introducing a new concept in the country that combines a hotel and a large multi-purpose venue. It will also open a new segment in Zambia's tourism industry, contributing to the desired economic diversification from mineral raw materials.

title: SLGP RSF Sogesol
content: The project is expected to have strong development impact in terms of: (1) supporting the growth of the productive sectors of the Haitian economy by expanding and increasing access to finance to small enterprises. The SME finance forum estimated that the total credit gap in Haiti amounts to almost US$2.5 billion, with 49% of MSMEs reporting that they are either under or unserved by financial institutions. (2) promoting growth in agribusiness, a key economic sector representing 22% of GDP.  It is estimated that only 28% of farmers have bank accounts and 19% received a credit for agricultural purposes. (3) strengthening the Haitian financial sector's competitiveness through capacity building, demonstration and replication channels.

title: KMF-HALP FY19
content:
Project outcomes - Stakeholders Effect: The most significant expected project-level outcome is derived from increased access to finance for underserved micro and small enterprises in remote areas of Kazakhstan and women borrowers by providing local currency financing to KMF, the largest microfinance player with strong outreach across the country. This Project, along with the previous projects, is addressing the microfinance gap in the country and providing sustainable financial access to micro and small enterprises in rural areas. 

Contribution to Market Creation - Inclusiveness: IFC anticipates that the Project can foster greater inclusiveness in the market through the expansion of microfinance services in rural areas of Kazakhstan by demonstrating the use of innovative digital underwriting tools, loan repayment infrastructure, and responsible finance practices to reach underserved segment.

title: SLGP PPCB Risk Sharing Facility
content:
(i)	Stakeholder impact - Effective risk mitigation: The Project will provide the Bank with an effective risk mitigation tool to sustainably increase lending to VSEs and SMEs, thereby increase economic activities of these underserved segments.
(ii)	Market-level impact - Inclusiveness: The small enterprise segments are not actively pursued by banks due to their higher perceived risks. The RSF is anticipated to help PPCB sustainably build its exposure to VSEs and SMEs, demonstrating the bankability of this client segment to other market players and increasing financing options for un/under-banked VSE and SMEs.

title: IEnova Corp.
content: The proposed investment has an Anticipated Impact Measurement and Monitoring ("AIMM") rating of "Good" based on an AIMM score of 65. The main project level outcomes are positive environmental effects from displacing carbon intensive thermal generation and reducing emission by 561,652 tons/year of CO2 equivalent and improving energy affordability for qualified users. Beyond the direct impact, the proposed investment is expected to contribute to diversify the country's energy supply, reducing reliance on thermal generation, gas imports and exposure to hydrology risk. In terms of competitiveness the proposed investment strengthens the expected trends of market price reduction and consolidation of new market structures.

title: Bog Transmicable
content:
The Transmicable project is part of a larger IFC engagement with the City of Bogota to support the development of the transport system; this engagement also entails the development of the Caracas Sur busway expansion. The overall expected development impact of this engagement is the following: 


1.Project level-outcomes: 

-Improved quality of transport service. The projects improve the quality to public transportation services particularly for low income users in Bogota. Transmicable connects a low-income area of the City (Ciudad Bolivar) to the City's main public transport system (Transmilenio BRT) and Caracas Sur entails the provision of exclusive bus lanes to a segment of the BRT network where traffic is currently mixed. The quality improvement will result from reduced congestion and increased frequency of service. Users are expected to save ~8.2 million hours per year (6.2 million Transmicable and 2 million Caracas Sur) which results in approximate savings for users of US$ 18.3 million (US$ 14.7 million Transmicable and US$ 3.6 million Caracas Sur) per year. 

-Environmental effect and climate change mitigation. The projects will reduce CO2 emission by approximately 445 tons p.a. on average during operation (134 Transmicable and 311 Caracas Sur) by replacing existing buses fleet and lowering congestion and travel times. 


2.Market Creation: 

-Integration. The projects will enable the development of new economic activities and clusters. Transmicable is part of an urban renovation project in Ciudad Bolivar. The plan entails the construction of parks, recreation centers and general service centers as well as promotion of businesses, tourism. The project puts in place infrastructure that enables the development of new economic activities (including commercial retail and recreational areas), thereby employment creation and promoting tourism in the area, among other activities. 

-Inclusiveness: the projects will continue demonstrating the transformational effect of redeveloping low income urban areas. Transmicable strengthens the evidence that increasing access to markets and services for low income areas generates viable opportunities for private sector participation, economic development and poverty reduction. The projects can serve as a model to be replicated in other low-income areas in Bogota and across Colombia.

title: Bogota Transmilenio
content:
The Caracas Sur busway expansion project is part of a larger IFC engagement with the City of Bogota to support the development of the transport system; this engagement also entails the development of the Transmicable project. The overall expected development impact of this engagement is the following: 

1.Project level-outcomes: 

-Improved quality of transport service. The projects improve the quality to public transportation services particularly for low income users in Bogota. Transmicable connects a low-income area of the City (Ciudad Bolivar) to the City's main public transport system (Transmilenio BRT) and Caracas Sur entails the provision of exclusive bus lanes to a segment of the BRT network where traffic is currently mixed. The quality improvement will result from reduced congestion and increased frequency of service. Users are expected to save ~8.2 million hours per year (6.2 million Transmicable and 2 million Caracas Sur) which results in approximate savings for users of US$ 18.3 million (US$ 14.7 million Transmicable and US$ 3.6 million Caracas Sur) per year. 

-Environmental effect and climate change mitigation. The projects will reduce CO2 emission by approximately 445 tons p.a. on average during operation (134 Transmicable and 311 Caracas Sur) by replacing existing buses fleet and lowering congestion and travel times. 


2.Market Creation: 

-Integration. The projects will enable the development of new economic activities and clusters. Transmicable is part of an urban renovation project in Ciudad Bolivar. The plan entails the construction of parks, recreation centers and general service centers as well as promotion of businesses, tourism. The project puts in place infrastructure that enables the development of new economic activities (including commercial retail and recreational areas), thereby employment creation and promoting tourism in the area, among other activities. 

-Inclusiveness: the projects will continue demonstrating the transformational effect of redeveloping low-income urban areas. Transmicable strengthens the evidence that increasing access to markets and services for low income areas generates viable opportunities for private sector participation, economic development and poverty reduction. The projects can serve as a model to be replicated in other low-income areas in Bogota and across Colombia.

title: SPV SistemCobro
content: The most significant expected project-level outcome is the off-loading of sizable amounts of DAs in the Target Region, reducing related NPL resolution costs and freeing up capital and funding, all of which will contribute towards new lending. In addition, the project will help to normalize the financial positions of defaulted debtors that are currently constrained to access formal credit. As a result of the project, IFC anticipates that this investment will promote greater sector competitiveness and integration via demonstration, replication, market enabling and innovation channels.

title: SEEMA hospital
content:
Improve accessibility: The Project provides a broad range of effective healthcare services and responds to the substantial gaps in the provision of healthcare. 
Improve affordability: The project expects to charge an average seven percent less than the average of current services provided by other private hospitals.
Market Creation - Competitiveness:  Project will result in significant increase in market competitiveness through better standards and new treatments to the market. In addition to providing competition for existing hospitals, this has potential to promote financing for other hospitals and help develop the market. A number of hospitals' expansion plans are currently on hold due to lack of financing.

title: Finandina Loan 2
content:
IFC's long-term financing is expected to improve access to finance for SME's, particularly those in the transport sector which is critical for Colombia. The project will also support Finandina's growth, improving the access to finance for SMEs thereby enhancing economic activity leading to job creation and economic dynamism.

Beyond the project-level impact, IFC anticipates that the project will create a demonstration effect for other financial institutions in Colombia in terms of the development of the digital channel.

title: Shifa Hospitals
content: This Project will extend access to quality affordable healthcare to patients and address gaps in health service provision witnessed in Pakistan and Tanzania. The Project will lead to better quality provision than is typically available in the market as both countries face underinvestment in adequate clinical infrastructure along with low quality and limited outreach of public sector healthcare. The clinical infrastructure will allow earlier diagnosis and treatment of patients in an outpatient setting at lower costs. Additionally, it will increase the competitiveness of the private healthcare sector by enabling a JCI accredited healthcare provider to expand operations in Pakistan and enter the Tanzania market.

title: Caribbean Bottling Company S.A.
content: (i) Project level impact is expected to derive from economy-wide effects through the creation of direct and indirect jobs, environmental and resource efficiency through improved practices in the production process, and access to safe drinking water  to a wider population in rural areas. (ii) anticipated Market level impact includes building up the local manufacturing base by aiming to source more inputs locally, initiatives to reduce plastic waste, and demonstration effect by investing in a country despite its various challenges.

title: Westfalia Moz II
content:
Project Outcomes: IFC expects the Project will i) create ~300 direct jobs during the first phase, (ii) further expand procurement from 50+ local farmers, who have formed an association and are eager to expand, and (iii) benefit local farmers from better output and more varieties given Westfalia's expertise in cultivar and seed development. 
Market Creation: i) Competitiveness: IFC expects the Project will increase competitiveness in the horticulture sector in the Catandica area of Mozambique, through demonstration and replication effects, ii) Integration: IFC expects that upon completion, the Project would expand fruit production in Mozambique to such a degree that it would justify the business case for a larger packing facility, which would increase integration along the supply chain, retain more value domestically, and create additional jobs.

title: VCT II
content:
1.	Modernization of the Logistic and Transport Support for the Growth of the Vast Indian Hinterland: The container terminal at Vishakhapatnam is the primary gateway for container traffic for the Indian states of Andhra Pradesh, Chhattisgarh and Odisha. The Project will double the existing container handling capacity enabling foreign trade in India's vast hinterland to pass through much more efficiently at lower the cost. The improved port will increase revenues for the government through royalty payments and taxes; more importantly, the increased foreign trade will provide more economic opportunity and create jobs for the people living in the hinterland states.

2.	Enhancing India's Strategic Collaboration with a Neighbouring Country: Due to its geographic location and the port conditions (deep-sea berths and convenient rail link), the container terminal expects to attract a significant amount of Nepal's foreign trade traffic volume, estimated at 100k TEUs per annum at present, after the improvement of the port capacity and facility. The Project will accommodate larger container vessels, allow for faster turnaround times and in conjunction with the direct rake service to Birgunj, improve the connectivity of Nepal, a land-locked country, with the global economy.

title: Lulalend
content:
Project outcome: stakeholders: Increased Access to Finance for SMEs. IFC's investment will allow Lulalend to grow its portfolio of uncollateralized loans targeted to micro and small enterprises. Lulalend serves customers with annual revenues ranging between ZAR500K and ZAR50MM ($36K - $3.5MM), with an average loan size of ~$10,000. Their primary target customers are those that have less than ZAR10MM ($700K) revenue per year. These firms are below the lending thresholds of traditional banks that typically offer them transactional services and wouldn't be able to access credit from formal sources. 89% percent of Lulalend's customers are estimated to be first time business borrowers. 

Contribution to market creation: Competitiveness: IFC anticipates that the Project will contribute to promoting systemic changes in the MSME lending market in South Africa in line with other investments made under the SME Push Program in the country. Lulalend specializes on MSME lending, maintaining low operating costs compared to banks and other full-service providers. We expect the success of Lulalend to contribute to greater competitiveness and innovation in the market through two channels: i) demonstrating the viability of extending credit to smaller MSMEs, leading new entrants, as well as existing financial service providers to emulate its business model and its products, ii) partnering with at least one larger financial institution in South Africa to serve these segments through partnerships or the development of white-label technology solution for serving micro and small enterprises.

title: Piramal Capital and Housing Finance Limited
content: 1. Access to housing finance: This Project will help in expanding the outreach of access to housing finance loans. IFC's support to PCHFL is aimed at supporting PCHFL's strategic intention to grow its affordable housing portfolio in a significant way in the near term.

title: Bolivariano II
content: Ecuadorian SME financing gap is estimated at US$15.73 billion, or 16% of GDP. Despite the significant role played by SMEs in the Ecuadorian economy as it produces 25% of GDP, the amount of lending to these companies accounts for only 3.6% of GDP, and 31% of SMEs report being fully or partially credit constrained. IFC anticipates that the project will increase access to SME finance and contribute to narrowing the financing gap for SMEs in Ecuador. IFC's loan to Bolivariano will allow the Bank to support its SME clients with longer-tenor loans.

title: Republic Bank Ghana Limited
content:
Stakeholders' Impact:

 - The Project is expected to provide long-term funding to SME borrowers. Longer-term financing is scarce in Ghana, and an especially binding constraint for some SMEs. According to the World Bank Enterprise Surveys, 5% of SMEs did not apply for a loan because maturity levels and loan sizes were inadequate. This is higher than the lower-middle income average of less than 2%.
- The Bank's current average tenor for SME loans is 12 months, and only 21% of loans have maturities over 36 months. The Project will enable the Bank to extend the average tenor of its loans to SMEs to 36 months. It is estimated that 72% of SMEs in Ghana currently do not have access to finance. The SME finance gap expressed as a percentage of GDP in Ghana was 13%, according to the most recent available IFC data (2017) and is likely to have widened over the past year in the context of asset quality issues in the banking sector, which caused banks to curb lending. 
- IFC anticipates that the Project will provide financing for 2,500 additional SMEs, increasing the Bank's SME reach in terms of number of loans to an outstanding portfolio of 4,500 SME loans worth US$330 million by 2023 from US$137 million as of December 2018. The Bank plans to increase the SME share of its overall loan portfolio from 51% as of 2018 to 65% by 2023, through increase in digital channels, leveraging RFHL's experience in providing SME banking to scale up their operations. The Bank's SME loan book is currently focused on the oil and gas, general trading, manufacturing, health, agriculture (non-traditional) and services sectors which make up about 80% of the Bank's SME loan book.

 Environmental and Social Impact: 

- Climate finance is a relatively new concept for banks in Ghana, with just a few banks in the country exploring green building finance.  However, the growth of climate finance has faced challenges primarily because of constraints of inadequate long-term funding and lack of dedicated incentives for developers. 
- Against this backdrop, Ghana's INDC states that the country needs US$22.6 billion to deliver on the Ghanaian government's climate commitments in accordance with the Paris Agreement. By on-lending over longer terms to an overlooked borrowing sub-segment in the country, the Project is expected to help reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 14,697.65 tons CO2. IFC will assist the Bank in defining its green finance strategy, identifying climate-eligible projects and training its staff in the areas of energy efficiency, climate-smart agriculture, and green buildings. 
- With 25% of the senior loan targeted at climate smart SMEs these stakeholders will benefit from access to longer tenured facilities for climate smart projects. 

Market Impact Assessment: 
Competitiveness:
 - Through a replication channel, the Bank's on-lending of longer-term finance to SMEs, with a focus on climate-smart SMEs, is expected to demonstrate to the wider local market that these are attractive investment subsegments.
 - As a mid-tier bank, the Bank is a seen as a market leader for smaller banks, which tend to follow its lead in the market. In addition, the rebranding exercise which took place in April 2018 has positively influenced the Bank's competitive position in Ghana, prompting both local and international banks operating in Ghana to begin following the Bank closely to ensure they can proactively respond to any new trends, products, and innovations introduced by the Bank, which leverages lessons from its parent, RFHL.
 - To this end, it is expected that the Bank's strategy to grow its SME book (including climate-smart SMEs) will be replicated by many of its competitors to keep up with the market.

title: Familiar CL
content: The Project will contribute to close the finance gap for MSMEs in Paraguay, leveraging the Bank's operational capacity to lend to this segment. In addition, IFC anticipates that the Project will have economy-wide effects by promoting job creation.

title: DCM L&TF
content:
1.	Increased access to farm equipment finance for rural farmers and very small enterprises (VSEs) in low-income states: The project will provide access to finance to farmers including those in low-income states with critical funds needed for them to modernize their farming techniques, thus enabling resource efficient growth.

2.	Inclusion & resilience: The success of this investment would enable further market development. This project is part of a programmatic approach under the liquidity facility for NBFCs in response to the recent liquidity shortage.

title: GWFP Mercon 2019
content: With its Leading Innovation and Farmers Traceability ('LIFT') program, Mercon is committed to improve levels of productivity, ensure positive environmental and social impact, and raise the living standards of coffee communities in the region.

title: Martur II
content: The Project's expected development impact includes (i) increased employment and skills development, (ii) value addition and supply chain linkages in Romania, Morocco and Algeria, and (iii) increased stakeholder benefits (i.e. customer benefits via better access to wider variety of components and parts; supplier benefits via additional domestic purchases). Beyond the project, IFC anticipates the investment will help increase the competitiveness in the auto-parts industry in Romania, Morocco and Algeria.

title: COMASA 2018
content: The project is being undertaken during a period of constrained financing in the country. Therefore, the Project will enable Comasa to preserve the existing level of production and exports, providing an access to market to peanut farmers. By maintaining production at its existing levels, the Project will help preserve jobs through a countercyclical intervention.

title: Continental CLII
content: The Project will contribute to close the finance gap for SMEs and agribusiness companies in Paraguay, leveraging the Bank's operational capacity to lend in these segments. In addition, IFC anticipates that the Project will have economy-wide effects by promoting job creation in the SME and agribusiness sectors.

title: Wildeklawer
content: IFC anticipates that this investment will strengthen sector sustainability and inclusiveness, through demonstration and replication channels. The development impacts are centered around: (i) Sustainability, by supporting the Company's climate smart interventions that reduce crop losses and spoilage, and increase productivity while reducing input use; (ii) Employment, whereby the Project is expected to create 130 new employees and provide skills training; (iii) The Company's stakeholders, namely their (a) suppliers through increased skills training and sales volumes, and (b) distributors/buyers through increases in the volume and quality of products to retail.

title: DCM Sugar
content:
a.	Investment in Priority Region in India: The Company would be investing in Uttar Pradesh, one of the key low-income states in India. This would help channel further private sector investment into the state.
b.	Farmer Productivity Gains: the client will seek to (i) improve farmer income through purchase of higher quantity of cane  and (ii) create small scale / micro entrepreneurs who can facilitate productivity gains for the farmers 
c.    	Jobs: create about 150 additional jobs through the project. 
d.	Demonstration effect: The Project will further demonstrate best practices and cleaner production norms in the Indian sugar industry.

title: PAE Campana Refinery
content: The Project is expected to (i) create value addition for Argentina by increasing supply of refined products in keeping up with the expected growth in demand, (ii) reduce emissions and lower sulfur dioxide levels, (iii) provide employment opportunities with direct and indirect job creation, and (iv) continue incorporating IFC's EH&S Performance Standards tools to set best practices for the sector.

title: NTB Syndication
content:
(i) Access to finance for SME, including WSMEs: An estimated 56,000 MSMEs lack access to adequate finance in Sri Lanka and through this project IFC will indirectly provide funding to SMEs over the next 5 years. The Project will also help reduce the formal financing gap for WSMEs which is estimated at US$416 million. 

(ii) Job creation: improved access to finance for SMEs is associated with both direct and indirect job creation.

title: Phoenix Tower B4
content:
Enhanced and expanded mobile telecommunications access: This Project expands tower sharing and enables mobile operators and internet service providers to share infrastructure cost and improve the quality and reach of their networks. In particular, the expansion will be achieved through the deployment of BTS sites for traditional coverage as well as small cell infrastructure which is an innovative technology in its nascent stage that brings better coverage to support data traffic in high density areas such as office towers and shopping malls. 

Expanded access to ICT technologies: The expected impact is on market competitiveness by supporting the growth of a second-tier provider deploying the innovation of small cell infrastructure that could potentially advance the market by pushing the incumbents to adopt the technology. While the tower sharing economy is moderately developed in Brazil with about 75,000 cell sites and 60,000 base stations deployed in Brazil with about 65% of the towers being independently owned, the tower sharing market is dominated by 3 large players who do not seem to be deploying the towers that are needed to support the higher data traffic densities required for 4G and 5G, or to be investing in small cell technology.

title: Earlybird II
content:
Increased access to risk capital for technology startup
Increased Investee Growth
Improved Competitiveness by catalyzing creation of other fund managers
Improved competitiveness in relevant target sectors by encouraging incumbents to leverage technology

title: Jointown Pharma
content: The Project will increase access to a wider choice of more affordable essential drugs patients in rural and frontier regions in Middle and Western China. The Project will also create 5,000 new direct jobs at the new facilities.  As a result of the Project, the Company is expected to increase procurement from SME suppliers thereby creating additional indirect employment opportunities.

title: CFPA MFI Gansu Revitalization and Innovation Loan
content: The most significant expected project-level outcomes include an increase in access to finance for about 79,749 micro and very small enterprises ("MVSEs"), including about 34,722 women borrowers, in Gansu Province. Beyond the Project, IFC anticipates that the investment will contribute to market creation through the promotion of market inclusiveness by encouraging more market participants to replicate CFPA MF's rural MVSE lending model and to focus more on the unbanked and underbanked rural women MVSEs, particularly in Gansu Province.

title: Sonoco
content: The most significant, expected project-level outcomes are (i) increased efficiency of the Port of Conakry; (ii) less traffic congestion at the exit of the Port and on the main road through Conakry; (iii) increased access to iron fortified bouillon cubes; and (iv) economy-wide effects associated with the growth of Guinea's nascent industrial sector.

title: FCS RE CIPREL V
content: (i) Provide competitive, reliable and clean base load power to help meet growing domestic demand and support the country's position as a regional exporter and help fuel the country's growing economy; (ii) displace more expensive and polluting plants (old units and/or plants running on HFO); (iii) contribute to lowering the average cost of generation and subsequently sector finances; and (iv) limit incremental emissions thanks to a state-of-the-art modern design.

title: Souff. Ethiopia
content: The project has an Anticipated Impact Measurement and Monitoring (AIMM) score of Good to Excellent. The most significant, expected project-level outcome is an increase in access to markets and support to increase productivity for more than 20,000 barley farmers. Beyond the project, IFC anticipates the investment will increase integration in the malt barley supply chain, through capacity building and demonstration and replication effects.

title: HKY2
content:
On the project level, the major impact is food safety and farmer income increase. 

On the market level, the impact relates to potential to strengthen competitiveness and integration in the domestic duck sector through demonstration of higher hygiene, resource efficiency and food safety standards to other market participants.

title: PMH Property
content:
1.	Job creation: The Project will create direct and indirect jobs through the development of the townships and purchases from local suppliers during and after construction. 
2.	Improved quality of life: PMH's developments create integrated and environmentally sustainable townships in Vietnam, which in addition to housing also includes commercial areas, public facilities, hospitals, schools and sports facilities. 
3.	Increase access to housing: The Project is expected to supply more than 5,000 housing units within the next 5-7 years.

title: Edita
content:
IFC's investment will help in:
(a) sustaining and creating new jobs in Egypt and Morocco (Edita's future growth will create 400 direct jobs per year in Egypt alone, totaling 2,000 over the next five years); and
(b) increasing integration of Egypt's processed foods sector, through capacity building and skills, as Edita will continue to support and develop local suppliers of raw materials, and these suppliers will supply other players in Egypt's processed foods sector.

title: Adjuvant
content:
Given the Fund's focus on the late stage in the development of many of the drugs, vaccines and diagnostics in the pipeline, it is reasonable to expect a large development impact on several fronts: 
(i)	improving access to high-impact treatment for millions of patients, and especially vulnerable populations (children and pregnant women) 
(ii)	possible replication of the business model and scale-up of the flow of additional funding into late stage development of drugs for neglected diseases; 
(iii)	by demonstrating the commercial viability of the proposed funding structure, this could prove to be an important catalyst for the development of drugs that otherwise would not be developed

title: Signature
content:
Accessibility (for consumers): The Project will increase the supply of affordable housing by approximately 8,000 units, across the National Capital Region, at a price point where good quality housing is severely lacking. 
Affordability (for consumers): Signature's housing units are typically priced substantially lower than the other units in conventional projects in the micro market. 
Inclusiveness: The Project will provide access to better health and social infrastructure (like schools, hospitals) while also improving safety, security and quality of living for its customers, the majority of whom belong to incomes below US$15,000.

title: Multiples Private Equity Fund III
content: The main project-level outcomes are: (i) increased access to capital from a domestic fund manager for underserved mid-cap companies, typically looking for growth capital; (ii) investee growth, which will be supported by the Fund Manager's value creation strategies; and (iii) support of a domestic Fund Manager bringing strong capacity-building and mentoring abilities, that can act as a catalyst for the domestic PE industry. In terms of market creation, IFC and the Fund Manager have been working to increase integration in the domestic PE market by attracting domestic institutional investors that have so far not supported domestic fund managers, thus strengthening the domestic capital market. Adding to the impact of this investment, the Fund Manager - being the only woman-led PE fund manager in India - leads by example in the market on the inclusiveness dimension.

title: A91 Partners
content:
Project outcome:
The Fund manager will provide access to growth capital for investees at an early stage of the companies' development, with ticket sizes of US$5-30 million, primarily to 10-15 small to medium-sized enterprises. IFC expects the value-creation strategies of the Fund Manager will increase investee growth; the Fund manager has an explicit strategy to support 1st-generation entrepreneurs who will bring tech-enabled solutions to disrupt traditional business models,  and would target SMEs that have reached an inflexion point and need capital to accelerate growth. The Fund Manager expects to generate high multiples and significantly above average returns.
The Fund Manager will transfer knowledge and operational value-add to investees, thanks to an active investment strategy, which will allow investees to increase market, technical, operational and business management
competence through sharing the insights of a peer group of entrepreneurs.
Contribution to Market Creation:
Beyond the project, if successful, this intervention is expected to increase competitiveness by a demonstration effect, through the strengthening of the domestic PE ecosystem, by improving domestic consolidation, by institutionalizing
